name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which is On 24 August, central Italy was shaken by a major earthquake. Damage was reported in more than 70 villages, and some communities were completely destroyed. We have all seen with great shock the images from Amatrice, Accumoli or Pescara del Tronto: more than 3 000 people have become homeless overnight and, from one day to the next, have literally stood in front of the rubble of their individual existence. On behalf of the European Parliament, I would like to begin by thanking the Italian civil protection, the fire brigade, the medical workers, the local authorities and all the volunteers: all those who helped to save lives, to provide protection and to guarantee primary care. The European Union will stand by the people in full solidarity. The earthquake caused severe material destruction. The villages that have been razed to the ground by these blows are not only Italian, they are also European cultural heritage. But the material damage disappears in the face of the human catastrophe and the pain of the families of the nearly 300 people who died. The houses, palaces and churches can be rebuilt and will certainly be rebuilt, but the emptiness left by the dead cannot be filled. In solidarity with the people and with the entire Italian nation, May I ask you to stand for a minute's silence from your seats. (The House rose and observed a minute's silence)

name: Sander LOONES
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. We are facing the most important negotiations the European Union has ever conducted in its history: the Brexit negotiations. Traditionally, in this Parliament, we are looking for a large majority across the various political groups. The reasoning is that we are so stronger in these negotiations, are stronger in relation to the Commission, stronger than the Council. And what do we see now? That last week Mr Verhofstadt was suddenly appointed to coordinate these negotiations for Parliament, as indicated by the Conference of Presidents. To my surprise, without debate, without a vote. That this is taking place! Then people often complain that there would be a democratic deficit. But when I see that even the leader of the group that calls itself the Liberals and Democrats is getting rid of such a debate and such a vote, I would ask that it be added to the agenda. I am also assuming that Mr Verhofstadt will be the first to enter into this debate with this Parliament as well.

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: – Mr President, we would like to support the ECR’s recommendation. I cannot believe that the Conference of Presidents have selected Mr Verhofstadt as someone who will be negotiating on behalf of the European Parliament regarding Brexit. I have been in this Parliament for six years and I have heard the ramblings of Mr Verhofstadt: I am telling you now, he is no friend of Britain.  The last time I spoke in this Parliament, I said that we need to be cool, we need to be calm, we need to ensure that we all get the best deal. Mr Verhofstadt’s appointment is no good for French farmers, and no good for British car manufacturers who sell a lot of cars into Britain. We need the best deal possible, and I ask you, please, to rethink Mr Verhofstadt’s appointment and come up with a more neutral candidate.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Mr President, first of all, I do not understand whether the debate is on the application of Article 50 or on Mr Verhofstadt. Secondly, I also do not understand that a debate is called for on the application of an article which no one has asked for to apply. Debating things that have not yet happened leads to melancholy. Thirdly, it does not make sense for the British Government to have asked for two years to decide whether or not to request the application of Article 50 and we will have to resolve it in two days. It's an inappropriate disproportion for the serious situation we're dealing with. Fourthly, I find it frivolous that such an important matter is intended to be resolved in the back, unannounced and hastily, in two days of parliamentary debate. It does not live up to the very serious problem facing the European Union. There is already a parliamentary procedure, and when the day comes that parliamentary procedure will be activated and this Parliament will debate. And let me tell you that they should be organised a little better, because at the same time that you want this Parliament to discuss Article 50 , which no one has asked to implement , the new British Commissioner who wants to be part of the governing bodies of the European Union will be examined in another chamber. Do one thing or the other, but both at the same time is contradictory. We're going to vote no, to avoid misunderstandings.

text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on the report by Werner Langen on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and energy on "Towards the Transformation of the Energy Market" (2015/2322(INI)) (A8-0214/2016) and – the report by Adam Gierek on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy on the EU Strategy for Heating and Cooling (2016/2058(INI)) (A8-0232/2016).

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, the debate on the future design of the energy market is, of course, a secondary issue in terms of the liberation of Vienna.  Today we are discussing the report presented by the Committee on Industry and trade in the matter, which was adopted by a good, large majority, with a view to the Commission's proposal of July 2015. Three policy objectives have been set for the future electricity market: firstly, to create an EU-wide electricity market with clear price signals for new investment. Secondly, a European approach to energy security should be established and, thirdly, regional cooperation in energy policy, in particular in investment in new energy generation plants, should be considerably strengthened.  As a result of the draft report, we have voted on a total of 590 amendments, which have been incorporated into a total of 36 compromises. The report covers the most important issues, that is, the question of the future design of capacity mechanisms, the promotion of renewable energies, the debate on price zones and distribution system operators, and the role of the European Energy Agency ACER.  The report sets out the direction for the legislative proposal to be presented by the Commission by the end of the year for a redesign of the energy market. Since the compromises have been largely broadly supported, it is quite possible to say that the most important steps towards harmonising the European internal energy market are included.  I would like to make a few brief comments as rapporteur on what the Committee on Industry has decided on: firstly, capacity mechanisms, which are paragraphs 25 and 24. Unnecessary or ill-designed mechanisms of this kind can lead to distortions of competition, to an impact on cross-border trade and to excessive electricity prices. The line adopted in committee provides that capacity mechanisms should continue to be possible if an EU-wide harmonised and transparent analysis of security of supply at regional level has shown that there is a need. This was not entirely uncontroversial, but we agreed on a wording that almost everyone could support.  The second issue is renewable energy , paragraphs 49 and 54. The Committee considers that the permanent subsidisation of renewable energies is no longer up-to-date. They, too, must respond to market signals in the new energy system. The report provides for a gradual phase-out of subsidies for mature renewable energies. It also highlights the risk of distortions caused by improper subsidies. Operators of renewable energy plants – and we know the intensive use of wind energy in the Nordic countries, including In Germany – must bear the consistent responsibility for the balance sheet. Priority network access will remain in place, but will be reviewed once the revamped energy market has been implemented.  Thirdly, the abolition of regulated prices and the debate on price zones, paragraph - 22. For the energy-only market to function properly, price spikes must generally be allowed, so that market price signals can also lead to investment and prices reflect the real energy shortage. This is not the case today, as can be seen from wholesale prices. Different price zones within a Member State must also be possible as an ultima ratio to reflect the actual energy shortage. And if we now see what diversions the electricity generated in northern Europe has to make in order to reach the consumer in the south, then that is an important issue.  The fourth point is that national responsibility for the energy mix, as laid down in the Treaties, should be maintained. Paragraph 47 refers to the Paris agreement on climate change, which takes account of the objective of gradual decarbonisation.  I added another two minutes for my group – a total of six minutes, Mr President!  Paragraph 53 rightly warns against the interlinking of supply targets with climate policy objectives. Separate votes have been requested here.  The fifth point is that distribution system operators, paragraphs 61 to 64. The report does not call for further unbundling beyond the third energy package. Distribution system operators should be neutral intermediaries, to whom a greater role is given.  Finally, the role of ACER, the European authority. It should be given decision-making powers in the coordination of cross-border issues, but not comprehensive monitoring of the energy market. can make a change.  Finally, I would like to thank all those who have contributed, especially the shadow rapporteurs – and now we have six minutes and two seconds of thanks!

name: Adam GIEREK
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Heating and cooling affects the processing of around 40% of total primary energy – a major energy problem – into around 50% of total usable energy in the form of heat.  While electricity generation can be harmonised in the single energy market, heating and cooling require local solutions. However, heating and cooling depend on the energy market, which, for example, on a local scale, can use cogeneration for both electricity and heat or cold production. The diversity of the need to ensure thermal comfort for Union citizens is demonstrated by the fact that the annual energy consumption span per square metre of heated area varies from around 60 to even 300 kWh in the Member States. The largest reserves of efficient use of heat are in the thermomodernization of about two-thirds of the so-called old substance of residential, public and commercial buildings, as the simplest, fastest way to use energy most efficiently, reduce CO2 emissions and create numerous jobs. This means that public funding and existing limits should be increased for this priority, e.g. in the Regional Development Fund, especially when it comes to entire settlements built in big plate technology, for example. Unfortunately, this issue has been marginalised by us in the past. It was a mistake. We lost a lot of time. Next, it becomes necessary to replace outdated district heating plants with so-called system heat from high-performance combined heat and power plants. It is necessary to eliminate outdated small, non-organic district heating plants and switch to heat from high-performance cogeneration systems. This may be facilitated, for example, by a temporary shift away from the use of ETS in these heat and power production systems.  Account must also be taken of the difference between the West and the East of the Union in the use of more efficient gas for heating purposes. This amount is many times higher in the EU's Western European countries, while in Central and Eastern Europe for heating purposes it has so far been mainly based on coal, which requires a gradual reduction in its inefficient combustion. This efficiency needs to be improved. The bane of the agglomeration of this region of Europe is low emissions, i.e. emissions into the atmosphere of incomplete combustion of organic pyrolytic gases, including aromatic hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides and soot, as well as fly ash.  In southern European Member States, the problem of seasonal cooling is on the rise due to global warming, which involves around 5% of the energy from the total amount of energy for heating and cooling. The issue discussed today requires the use of many comprehensive forward-looking solutions, including: architectural and urban; use of natural heat and cooling sources. It requires the urgent development of innovative research and the creation of an entire industry of new thermal insulation materials and sustainable technologies for ecological heating and cooling with a particular focus on solar panels and reverse heat pumps.  In the future, the thermal comfort of the people of the European Union will depend primarily on zero-emission thermomodernization and on the optimal use of renewable energy sources for the whole climate zone.  Colleagues, priorities are known, but they should also be prioritised and implemented, according to a different hierarchy of importance in different Member States, because this will guarantee us the optimisation of the solutions achieved and the fight against energy poverty.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking this House, and in particular the two rapporteurs, for their supportive work on these two important files. Starting with the Langen report, I am very glad that this House shares our commitment to promoting a more market—oriented, flexible and decentralised energy system providing the right investment signals for the energy transition. Ultimately we need a system that puts prosperity and the decarbonisation of our economy at its very heart, and our review of market design rules will be key to that end. On the one hand, thanks to the three consecutive legislative packages, we have introduced competition to varying degrees in different markets and more cross-border flows of electricity. But, on the other hand, we have not yet managed to adapt our market framework sufficiently to the challenges that decarbonisation, and in particular the massive roll-out of variable renewable generation, have brought along. Adapting our energy system to the new challenges will require action on at least four fronts. First, we have to ensure that the new market design will work for consumers by making them more active market participants. Innovative and smart technologies are available but they are not properly used in many cases because the right regulatory framework is not there. Wholesale and retail markets must be more closely linked, giving consumers access to a wider choice of products, and consumers must be able to market their flexibility by removing obstacles for aggregators to enter the market. Second, we need electricity markets to give the right investment incentives for a successful energy transition by strengthening price signals. This means the price must be able to rise when demand is high or generation is scarce. Constraints on pricing must be removed, as a matter of the first order, so as to reward flexibility. It is in this context that our reforms will be aimed at promoting shorter markets. The integration of the European Union—wide intraday and cross—border balancing markets must be significantly accelerated. Third, a more integrated energy market will also require us to find new ways of deepening our cooperation across borders on all levels. But full market integration will also require the seamless cooperation of transmission system operators (TSOs) at operational level, and we will need to look at ways of strengthening regional TSO cooperation based on existing approaches. Likewise, more cooperation between regulators will be needed to match closer TSO cooperation and this includes reviewing the role of the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER). Lastly, while the aim of this exercise is to strengthen the internal market, public policy interventions are likely to remain a part of the reality. We will therefore need a stronger framework to ensure that such measures are compatible with the internal market. The most urgent issue is dealing with the generation adequacy policies that we see emerging in a number of Member States. In many cases these follow a purely national logic and focus exclusively on introducing measures to remunerate national generation capacities, without taking account of the benefits of market integration. This is not a viable approach and, if left untouched, it seriously risks distorting the internal energy market. That is why we will propose a European or regional framework for capacity remuneration mechanisms. The main purpose of such a framework will be offer a common approach to assess the adequacy of energy systems. From the Commission’s point of view, it is crucial that such an assessment takes into account the contribution of capacity across the border to security of supply. Likewise, when a capacity mechanism is introduced, such cross-border capacity, as well as demand response, must be able to participate. As a principle, this is already the case but with our proposals it must become a reality. Last but not least, let me pick up on another key point mentioned in the report. It is all well and good to update our market design, but we must absolutely commit ourselves to ensuring the effective implementation of the system legislation. That will continue to be a priority for the Commission. We will of course look at the report in detail as we prepare our proposals and I look forward to coming back to this House to present them later this year. Turning now to the Gierek report on heating and cooling, this report highlights the fact that this sector could be an absolute game changer when it comes to energy security, economic growth and reaching our energy and climate targets. The report places emphasis on the ‘energy efficiency first’ principle and the push for renewables to replace fossil fuels. It focuses on building renovation and the deployment of modern and smart technologies and systems, and highlights the need to reinforce the capacities of citizens, industries and public authorities through better information, awareness, training and education, research and innovation and targeted capacity—building initiatives. These all go in the direction of the Commission. Let me remind you that heating and cooling in our buildings and industry account for half of European Union energy consumption and are largely powered by fossil fuels. Seventy-five percent of our buildings are energy inefficient and are mostly fitted with old boilers with low efficiency rates. That is why our study focused on removing barriers to decarbonisation in buildings and industry. We need to link up heating and cooling to electricity networks and to renewable energy more effectively. That will reduce costs for consumers and provide storage for valuable energy. Our market design proposals will provide the flexibility and demand response to make that happen, and our upcoming review of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive will prepare the ground for making buildings smart and ready for the new solutions. Under the revised Renewable Energies Directive, we will be aiming at further integrating renewable energies of all types in this sector, but we also need to speed up renovation rates. Our implementation work, combined with the upcoming review of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive and the Energy Efficiency Directive, will strengthen the drive to replace inefficient boilers faster and incentivise renovations in multi—apartment buildings. To do that we also need to make the right financing available. The good news is that we have started to do that through the European Fund for Strategic Investments and we will back that up with an initiative to help facilitate access to new innovative funding mechanisms. Both of these reports highlight how important it is that we get on with building the energy union that this House has supported since day one. The reports in our debate here today are a solid basis from which we can get to work on the whole range of legislative files that are coming up in the next weeks and months.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Thank you, President. For the first time, heating and cooling is being talked about as a separate energy sector, which is, by the way, one of the largest, consuming about 50 percent of the energy produced. I would like to congratulate the Commission on the preparation of such a comprehensive and detailed study. The action plan presented will help to improve the energy efficiency of buildings, integrate advanced technologies and renewable energy sources. Member States' heating and cooling needs vary according to climate, building stands or heat farms. Strategies must therefore be flexible and each country must find the most appropriate way to achieve optimal efficiency in the heating sector. Local and regional authorities, the real implementers of the strategy, play an important role. When I work on this report, I have heard on a number of occasions that one of the main problems is that cities do not have enough specialists and experience to help them fully assess and plan heat farm efficiently. Often waste heat from the industry is not used because of bureaucracy, renovation is single, not complex, so the existing potential is not exploited. Measures and favourable conditions need to be developed to help this level to make appropriate, economically sustainable, long-term solutions. The added value of the European Commission here is obvious. It has a general view of the sector and expertise. I am convinced that the Commission should develop a harmonised and comprehensive set of urban energy planning measures to assess the potential of local heating and cooling energy, optimise and integrated renovation of buildings and the development of heating and cooling infrastructure. I think it is equally important to concentrate efforts both on accelerating the renovation of buildings and on the renewal of heating and cooling systems. As we can see from the experience of different countries, attractive financial incentives have excellent results and do not necessarily include only state support, it can also include preferential loans, guarantees or municipal programmes.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European energy sector has changed. We have moved from centralist energy production to more flexible models, organised on decentralised production, on the integration of technologies from renewable sources, with the aim of overcoming national protectionism that risks undermining the construction of the European Energy Union.  Today, the aim is to update the market rules: a commitment that is not easy because it means getting to the regulatory framework of the European energy sector and at the same time putting our finger in the energy dynamics of the Member States.  I would like to make three points which I consider to be important in the Langen report. The first is an approach that integrates production from renewable sources at all stages of the market – production, networking, storage, distribution, opening up to new markets of small producers. A concrete commitment, therefore, towards the energy transition towards a decarbonised development model, in line with the objectives of last December's Framework Resolution on the Energy Union.  Secondly, a market vision that looks at technological and management innovation in a European way, in order to increase the potential of storage, for the virtuous management of supply and demand, for investments in transmission, for overcoming market bottlenecks, those that tend to confine energy potential all within their respective Member States. Each Member State will therefore have to pursue the security objectives individually, but the European legislator will indicate a forward-looking path for the energy market, which will no longer be the sum of different national experiences, but an organic and credible design.  In this regard, I welcome the parts that go into the distorting aspects of the electricity market and that we must overcome in the future: it is capacity mechanisms and technology support schemes. The former must guarantee certain capacities and can no longer be designed on a national basis, but must be transnational in nature. The latter, renewable energy support schemes, have played an important role, but they need to be reviewed on the basis of the degree of maturity of their renewable technologies.  Overall, therefore, it is a high text. I hope that this Parliament will support it.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr Langen's report addresses a key issue – what the electricity market in the European Union should look like in the long term. From the ECR group's perspective, there are many positive elements, in particular the call for the marketisation of renewable energy sources and, in the long term, the end of subsidies. This subsidy is becoming an increasingly distortive element of the market, it is becoming increasingly absurd, and I think that is the element that needs to be emphasised in this report.  However, the pursuit of a common electricity market should not serve as a pretext for the Union to take responsibility for shaping the energy mixes of individual countries. The choice of energy sources must remain the responsibility of EU countries. Unfortunately, this element has not been duly emphasised in the rapporteur's report, although, as the rapporteur mentioned, it has been taken into account.  Another, even more important problem of this report is the rapporteur's sceptical attitude towards the so-called power markets. Capacity markets are crucial when it comes to securing electricity supply in individual Member States. In addition, capacity markets provide the necessary support for renewable sources (renewable energy), which will have to be insured for a long time by traditional forms of energy generation. Capacity markets are therefore necessary to change the situation, guarantee stability for investors and secure supplies.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - My fellow Member, I would like to thank you for your support. I don't really want to argue with you. You say – and there are many who agree with you – that the development of the energy mix is a competence of the Member States. But do you think that a principle could be established in the European institutions so that, say, by 2030 the share of fossil fuel energy in the energy mix is zero?

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – As I said, It seems to me that, leaving aside the very long-term perspective, at the moment the energy mix is within the competence of the Member States and the Member States should be able to decide for themselves how they will achieve the objectives that we set ourselves in terms of renewable energy sources and other such issues. On the other hand, this should not be the subject of interference by the EU authorities and the Commission. This should remain the responsibility of the Member States, because the Member States know best how to achieve the objectives that we set ourselves.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I can either repeat what Mr Langen has already eloquently said in the report – which I fully back, although maybe on one or two issues, like the capacity mechanisms, I would appreciate stronger language but I really fully back the report and I think it is a balanced one – or I can instead make a political point, and I would like to do exactly that. If we look today at the market, whether it is gas or whether it is any other source of energy, it is not economically viable to invest. That is the situation: that is what we are facing today and, unless we want to maintain that situation, we need to create different conditions. I believe this is the key issue. Of course, cooperation among the Member States – on the original approach, the market signals, the level of protectionism, which is too high, and the national approach – is vital. So my point today is that we have a balanced report, which addresses the right issues. In fact, if we have listened to the Commissioner, I think these two positions and points of view very much merge. So what I hope is that tomorrow, when we vote on the report, we will give it strong support and send out a signal to the Member States, which clearly, on the basis of the Third Package, still do not comprehend the situation fully.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The question is what to do with an electricity market design in the age of COP 21. Our aim is to do everything possible to achieve the climate targets, while at the same time providing everyone with sufficient affordable energy. And in this dual function we see no contradiction, on the contrary: a consistent 'yes' to the advance of renewables creates a future, and that is for everyone. And it is precisely because there is a clear 'no' in response to existing and envisaged capacity mechanisms, because there is overcapacity in a number of countries and because it primarily uses fossil fuels. This is a problem, and we have often addressed it.  We are also concerned about the constant calls for any subsidy for renewables to be reduced. I believe that this is a strategic mistake and, in the end, a competitive disadvantage. We have often argued about ignoring the fact that coal, gas and oil continue to be subsidised. In 2015 alone in Germany, this alike 49.2 billion, which flowed directly and indirectly.  What we need is not subsidies there, but actually more focus on renewables. We still need subsidies. We need the feed-in priority. What we do not need, for example, are solar taxes, and we must not neglect the rights of consumers. Smart meter is good, but it must not be used for monitoring.

name: Claude TURMES
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we are at a difficult moment in our power market in Europe. Why? because we are confronted with extreme over—capacities in most of the markets. Why do we have these extreme over-capacities? Because of the failure of the EU CO2 trading regime. With CO2 prices of EUR 7 or 8 per tonne, and no prospect of that changing with the actual proposals on the table, coal power stations which, politically, Europe decided to phase out when it adopted its climate package in 2008, will stay in the market.  So what do we do in that situation? What are we saying in the Langen report? The first thing is, do not go for capacity payments. It would be completely counter-productive. Why should we pay the coal power stations to stay alive?  Commissioner, when you say that you want consumer orientation, in Denmark there has been a very detailed analysis which says that a strategic reserve – so just keeping some power plants in reserve for an extreme moment, but outside the market – is ten times cheaper for consumers than capacity payments. Why should we go for capacity payments if, firstly, they keep the old, dirty power plants in the market and, secondly, they are more expensive for the consumer?  The very clear message which we are giving – and this is also thanks to the Socialist Group – is that we want to keep priority access and dispatch for renewable energy. Why is that important? Because when you have over—capacity in a market, there will be situations where you have to curtail, where you have to decide whether it is a coal power plant running, or whether it is renewable energy running. So you, Commissioner, who was a champion in Paris, how could you penalise renewals by taking away priority access and dispatch? Because if we take priority access and dispatch away, then we will have a purely economic merit order of curtailment, and renewables will be the first to be shut down. Do we want a market where renewable investments are penalised? I do not think so. Look at our report, and think again; no capacity payments. If we need to think about something, then it should be more strategic reserve and, secondly, priority access and dispatch for renewables are necessary as long as the CO2 market is a failure, and as long as we have such huge over-capacity.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we agree that the energy market must be radically redesigned in order to speed up the energy transition, decentralise production and help achieve the Union's climate and energy objectives.  To this end, the current structure based on a few large conventional plants must be transformed in order to increase local production from renewables, giving more space and voice to smaller and less organized producers, such as prosumers and cooperatives, and to new services associated with them.  Unfortunately, the Langen report, in our humble opinion, does not sufficiently reflect these needs, although it is much, much improved – we thank it for this – during the shadow meetings, for the way it emerged from the vote in committee, but references to fossil and nuclear energy persist and the position on combating capacity mechanisms, which are in fact disguised subsidies to fossil sources, is not as clear as we would like. At the same time, we would like to eliminate subsidies for renewables, which we would also accept if negative externalities on health, ecosystems and climate were always taken into account in the cost of fossil energy and nuclear power: then we could really talk about the free market!  Instead, we welcome the Gierek report, which creates the necessary balance between decarbonisation and technological foresight, gradual but decisively reducing fossil fuels, and because of the importance it gives to smart and efficient buildings and smart appliances. We do not really agree on the incineration of waste, we have doubts about certain forms of heating and biogas, but we will see how the amendments will go in plenary during the vote.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner Caete, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work This report on a new energy market design is in line with the Commission's requirements and is very good at them in terms of security of supply and improved regional cooperation. The report will also help to increase the functioning of the European internal market and to a more market-based approach. I would like to thank the rapporteur for this. The main points of this report are certainly the improvement of the regulatory framework, especially when it comes to feeding in an increased share of renewable energies, decentralisation in order to stimulate investment and, in particular, to enable SMEs to have better access to the energy grid and also to balance the grids, the position of the prosumers – for the first time a call for a chapter on prosumers in the Renewable Energy Directive has been made here – more transparency in price signals. , in particular to make market prices better received by consumers, and higher system adequacy in the area of regional cooperation, higher interconnectivity and an adequate importance of storage. However, there will be some sharpening – as has already been mentioned briefly today – particularly when it comes to cross-border price zones. Here I would like to mention the Austrian-German price zone, where the German Minister for Economic Affairs in particular is now calling for the introduction of bottleneck management with Austria and where unilateral action is also possible: this should be prevented as far as possible. This is where the price zone works. However, individual regulatory details at the micro level must also be taken into account. In general, I believe that, in the area of capacity mechanisms, it is still unclear how Parliament ultimately stands on strategic network reserves and market-based capacity-securing mechanisms.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Mr President, since the Paris climate meeting, energy issues in this Chamber can only be discussed as a subsea of climate policy. It is perhaps no coincidence that the report also sets out the objectives of 'climate and energy' – when it comes to the electricity market. And perhaps it is no coincidence that the Commissioner for the Energy Union, Šefčovič, does not represent the Commission in this matter. Of course, I also believe that the objectives of the Paris meeting must be met. But many are setting more ambitious targets - they do not take security of supply into account. It means that renewable energies have fluctuating performance and therefore have a limited share of renewable energies within a system. They don't take affordability into account. Not all countries are as rich as Germany to pay a huge sum to take over renewable energy. And among low-carbon technologies, they only talk about renewables – when there is nuclear power, which is clean energy. And I would add that in 2014, american environmental scientists announced that nuclear energy should be counted on for a long time from the point of view of climate protection. And one more note: energy security is an existential issue for a country. This responsibility cannot be taken out of the hands of national governments.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Mr President! There is no doubt that both reports play an important role in bringing about more sustainable development together. There is a need to create a better internal energy market. There is a need to use the energy at our disposal much better. Not least when we talk about heating and cooling there are good opportunities to do better. As you know, we import much more energy into Europe than is necessary. Cooling and heating is an area where we can do extremely better in terms of using the energy that is available. We are wasting billions of euros on importing gas and oil from Russia and the Middle East respectively. The money could be used much better if we prioritised energy efficiency higher. When we talk about energy efficiency, it is of course a common thread that I would like to see go through the proposals that lie ahead, and I hope that it can be implemented in the forthcoming legislation. Investing more in energy efficiency is also the best way to reduce CO2. At the same time as making savings, we are also giving the industry behind it a much greater opportunity to innovate and create new products that can compete on the world market. There are many places other than Europe that require change in this area, and this will enable us to sell good products. On top of the fact that we can conserve our energy and use it better, it is also a place where we can create a lot of jobs and a lot of growth in the future.

name: Dan NICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to stress the importance of the two reports in this debate, 'EU Strategy for Heating and Cooling' and 'Towards a new organisation of the energy market'. By the end of this year, the Commission will come up with new legislation on energy efficiency, energy market organisation and energy performance of buildings - legislative proposals with a major role in achieving the objectives of the Energy Union and with the impact that we want positively on jobs and the industry of the European Union. I believe that we need to insist and take more care of jobs and industry, without which the European Union cannot be competitive. It is clear that we need a forward-looking reorganisation of the energy market that takes into account new energy realities: the need to incorporate renewable energies into the grid, wider tariff areas, short-term trading markets and, of course, the physical infrastructure to enable all of this. With regard to capacity mechanisms, they should be used as a last resort to balance the network, as they would put too much financial pressure on consumers.  Since heating and cooling account for around half of the European Union's final energy demand, it is important that the sector becomes more efficient, in order to reduce dependence on energy imports, to help reduce emissions, and to reduce costs for consumers, especially those at risk of energy poverty.  I stress once again the importance of ensuring access to finance, both in the short and long term, for investments in projects related to the modernisation of the heating and cooling sector, including for district heating and cooling, modernisation of current infrastructure networks, modernisation of heating systems and for the transition to renewable sources. Mandatory energy deficiency targets must be accompanied, I repeat and stress, by adequate access to finance. Congratulations to my colleagues, Mr Gierek and Mr Zanonato for their contribution and outstanding work in producing these two very good reports.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: – Commissioner, the European Union's heating and cooling strategy is fundamental to the impact of Community efforts in the areas of reducing harmful carbon emissions, the use of renewable energy sources, energy independence, environmental protection and sustainable development.  The document is an extremely in-depth analysis of energy consumption for heating and cooling and gives national governments excellent guidance on environmental and energy efficiency policies. The benefits of adopting and implementing this strategy will affect most households within the European Union, as well as almost every business, industry and institution that uses a building stock for its activities.  The key word that largely unites the conclusions of the strategy is synergy. On the one hand, synergy between renewable energy sources, which must be increased relative to the use of fossil fuels occupying 75% of primary energy for heating and cooling. On the other hand, synergy between the urgent need for the production and mass deployment of energy-saving appliances, renovation of the building stock and implementation of innovations in the field of centralised heating and industry, which are in fact the largest users of energy from depleted sources. Through the implementation of the strategy, the European Union will support the development of small hydropower plants, biomass processing, solar, wind, geothermal power plants, biofuels, rain, tide and other innovative methods of recreational energy sources.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Mr President! In the coming days, we can expect a flurry of legislation in the field of energy. Legislation which is absolutely essential to the green transition in Europe. We need a progressive and ambitious line, which is why it is good that we now have a strategy for heating and cooling - it is high time, because we know that the energy consumption of European citizens is precisely spent on heating up houses or cooling them down. If we are serious about the green transition, we need the heating and cooling part. We will have major tasks in this House in the coming days. I would like to appeal to us to seek a holistic approach to legislation. Otherwise, we risk a silo thinking in which we do not optimise our systems and thus waste opportunities that we might otherwise have exploited. We need to get better at integrating renewable energy into district heating. When we talk about energy efficiency, we must not just talk about insulation, we need to discuss how interaction between our technologies can ensure maximum benefit from the least possible energy. In the context of the excellent report on market design, we must integrate new technology into the network and pay close attention to how consumers act with the new opportunities. The ambition must be a coherent energy system for the benefit of all of us. This requires a focus on solutions, not technologies per se.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). – Ladies and gentlemen, the abolition of national policies and the strengthening of the Commission's powers to unify the market and the creation of a pan-European electricity market as proposed in the report will have disastrous consequences for consumers. Only large companies will be the winners as they will be able to operate and operate seamlessly by increasing their profits. For those of us on the left, it is clear that energy must be guaranteed as a public social good to which we all have equal and cheap access. It is equally important that the provision of energy to citizens should be a matter of national policy determined on the basis of the needs of the country and the people, always with a view to social development. Finally, the design of the electricity market should be based on a comprehensive proposal to support and develop renewable energy sources, which is also absent from the report. We will therefore vote against the report because its sole objective is to make energy a tool to strengthen the major private interests and competitiveness in the Union.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr If we are to be able to implement a green realignment of Europe's energy system, the electricity market needs to be organised in such a way that we use resources more efficiently. Our historical, national borders are rarely the best geographical division for our energy markets, which could be allowed to function better with new geographical divisions. By increasing interconnection between regional energy markets, we will have a lower energy price and, on the other hand, we would also use our resources more efficiently when we can have the electricity system in one part of Europe and be the reserve for another. When the sun is not shining in one country, you can use the wind power from another or the hydropower of a third. In order to meet the climate threat, an energy market and its design are required that produce more renewable energy. We fight for that.

name: Julia REID
text: – Mr President, we in UKIP object both to the EU strategy on heating and cooling and the Commission’s new energy market design. It is clear that the EU strategy on heating and cooling would be used to reinforce the disruptive EU energy and climate policy that has already brought irreparable damages to the European industry and economy. With regard to the new energy market design, we opposed the implementation of the Third Energy Package in all Member States. The disaster of the EU over-commitment to unreliable, intermittent and hugely expensive renewables has now made clear that the EU climate policies have done far more economic damage than anything that could be envisaged as a result of climate change. They have forced up prices, undermined competitiveness and driven energy-intensive industries out of the EU altogether, taking their jobs and investment with them. The UK as an independent country will soon be free to choose how to make its own energy policy and to exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to the administrative experience of proximity made before today at municipal, provincial and regional level, I will try to provide you all with what I believe is the real worldview that it struggles, with commitment, passion and mastery, to produce for us too. The real worldview that is compass, must be compass of good work.  Unfortunately, in twenty years of pro-liberalisation European policies on markets, energy, water and transport, we are in fact witnessing a lack of accessibility, a substantial increase in tariffs for citizens and businesses, an increase in response times, less efficiency of service and a lack of transparency in the bill. Furthermore, in the report we find a spasmodic use of the word 'simplification': be ware, because this step certainly simplifies the possibility of closing down quickly for small and medium-sized enterprises and simplifies the increase in the unemployment rate. Yes, if we do not reverse the direction of travel, it will be easier to be out of work. Thank you, long live Lombardy.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, the strategy to redesign the energy market is a prime example of the implementation of a bad EU economic policy. A combination of measures which, in addition to renewable energy sources, must also take into account production technologies with lower emissions of pollutants is promoted. A strategy that benefits the environment and people. However, the planned creation of a single pan-European carbon tax will place a burden on holders of Union passenger and corporate vehicles in addition to the increased taxation already in place at national level. We plan to adopt practices against the principles of proportionality – and I am talking about the polluter pays principle – but also to avoid any double taxation by ignoring the principle of subsidiarity. The interconnection of energy production and distribution sectors and the development and adoption of innovative technologies should not be financed by overtaxation measures for Union citizens. They can be financed by taxation of large energy production and distribution companies, especially those that do not invest in renewable and environmentally friendly sources.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs – Mr Gierek and Mr Langen – very warmly for their two excellent reports. I am now speaking on Mr Langen's report and I would like to highlight the points that are particularly important to me. Firstly, regional cooperation - strengthening regional markets. I think that is very important. On the road to a European internal market, we simply need integration within the framework of regional markets. Secondly, with regard to the development of renewable energies, I think it is right and proper that the report states that we do not want permanent subsidisation of renewable energy systems and that we must move towards a market economy in the direction of feed-in tariff systems. Perhaps at some point we will come to a European feed-in tariff system. In the meantime, however, it is important to support the market economy accordingly. Incidentally, I was also pleased that this report also mentioned hydropower. My third point is that electricity storage is a very central and essential part of the report. That has not been mentioned today; I think that is fundamental. The more we develop renewables, the more important this issue becomes and the more we have to invest in research and development in the field. And last area: capacity markets. I know that they are not, of course, conducive to integration, but they are, in any case, a necessary evil for a transitional period, as long as we do not have the integration of the European internal market. In this respect, I think it is a good thing that we are dealing with the issue here and want to establish specific conditions under which capacity markets are allowed nationally.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, we are laying the foundations for what should be an Energy Union based on an interconnected market capable of ensuring electricity supply at affordable prices, with the optimal use of energy resources and efficiency as pillars, and integrating renewable energy and co-generators by the citizens themselves. This objective requires increasing interconnections in the internal market, the deployment of smart grids that wipe out energy islands, such as the Iberian Peninsula. Commissioner, heating and cooling account for about half of the European Union's energy demand; hence the importance of improving energy efficiency in this area, to reduce dependence, to reduce emissions and costs for consumers and, in particular, to those at risk of energy poverty. In short, we must place the citizen at the centre of setting up the new energy market.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, a well-functioning energy market is very important to all of us. Apparently, energy tax refunds have become a major tax subsidy machine for some large international companies. They also offset more than 95 per cent of the EUR 200 million tax subsidy pot in Finland.  In Finland, most tax subsidies are offset by the paper industry. According to VATT's research, a large proportion of companies that received energy tax refunds had no competitiveness problems at all, but were even more productive than average before the tax refund machine. Consequently, the State loses EUR 200 million in tax revenue each year without getting any value for money. If energy production is supported, I would like to see support money channeled into promoting small-scale and low-emission solutions close to the consumer and improved energy efficiency in the future.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In order to create a European Energy Union, we need a major toss: the profound and market-based transformation of the energy market, together with the implementation of existing legislation. I am convinced that we in Europe deserve a competitive, transparent and liberal internal market in the field of energy. Only in this way can we guarantee the energy supply for European citizens and at the same time create better conditions for consumers. This requires some fundamental changes in the current system: first, we need to ensure that we set up a market-based energy system. These include, in particular, the abolition of regulated prices and the creation of better price signals for investment in energy. In the field of renewable energies, too, it is clear that these must be better integrated into the energy market. More flexibility and a market-based system are needed here. We must realise that the current support system is no longer up-to-date and that we need to find more competitive and adaptable solutions.  Another important point is regional cooperation between the individual Member States. Here we must promote the targeted development of interconnectors and increased regional cooperation. I am sure that only a holistic market transformation will create a successful European internal energy market.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which There is talk of a decentralised and flexible market that we want to create here. In the same sentence, however, it is stated that a regulated market-based system should be created. That, ladies and gentlemen, is the exact opposite of what was first said. You have to decide what you want. They recognize that we have different local situations, both in terms of resources and energy needs. You recognise that the Member States continue to decide on the energy mix, and yet you believe that you can create something like a market when you have 28 different national rules. This borders on a Babylonian language confusion, but has little to do with the market. At the same time, you want to get consumers with smart grids, which will incur costs, which will interfere with their civil rights, which makes surveillance possible. This, ladies and gentlemen, has nothing to do with a sensible European market.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: – Mr President, we are debating today an extremely important report for the European economy, the achievement of the single energy market, a market that we want to be functional and efficient. There is progress, but we still have bottlenecks in achieving this goal. Firstly, it is insufficient investment and a very slow pace for the interconnection of national energy networks. Secondly, we are talking about an still insufficient harmonisation of national energy legislation. We have countries where getting a permit to connect a business to national energy networks takes over a hundred and fifty days. Finally, thirdly, we are talking about the failures caused by some renewable energy stimulus policies, which have led to excessive costs for intensive, essential, strategic industries for the European Union.  I support the proposed compromise amendments because they help to remove these bottlenecks.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. According to the Renewable Energy Progress Report, which was recently adopted by the European Parliament, two Member States have serious problems in reaching their renewable energy targets by 2020, one of which Hungary. This situation is no accident, since the Hungarian Government, in order to try to prove that the expansion of the Paks nuclear power plant it is planning could be profitable, wants to limit the uptake of renewable energies in Hungary at all cost. Thus it was possible that a special tax was imposed on solar panels, and thus the unique thing that happened was that wind farms were actually banned in Hungary recently. What was not sorely needed was that in the last 10 years no wind farm could be built in the country. The reason is simple: this is how they try to make the expansion of the Paks nuclear power plant profitable. But we all know that this will end in Europe's most expensive electricity and huge construction corruption, so we must do everything we can to prevent the expansion of the Paks nuclear power plant.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: – A bold policy, both the European strategy for heating and cooling and the proposal for a new energy market are essential for the realisation of our European Energy Union. We need to remove the energy borders between the Member States. What do we see today? That far too many rules, but also literally physical boundaries, are a stumbling block to create an efficient energy market. It is a pity that the report calls for Brussels to define the energy mix of the Member States. It is the Member States themselves and the market that have to determine them, not the Commission's DG Energy. The large energy savings can be achieved in the heating and cooling sector. I am therefore very satisfied with this strategy. We must first of all focus on increased efficiency: lower energy consumption through technological applications, among other things, but also the reuse of heat from industrial processes are interesting.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: –  Mr President, the wholesale electricity markets were designed for a different time – a time where there were no renewable energies, or there was much less renewable energy and technology. The current design is clearly not fit for the integration of more renewables into the market. It is not bringing the necessary flexibility for the market to function properly. Innovation provides us with new solutions that make it possible to bring that flexibility: automatic switches; new storage solutions; and also data—driven solutions like data hubs or platforms. Digital solutions are crucial, for instance, to send the right price signals for making demand and response work. The new market design needs to be innovation-driven and to provide a smarter way of storing and using power. This is important for the market participants as well as energy consumers.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I welcome the Commission's proposal as well as the proposal for this report that properly ponders the European Union's heating and cooling strategy. In the European Union, almost 50% of final energy demand is used for heating and cooling, of which 80% is used in residential buildings. This energy consumption is dependent on fossil fuel consumption at a ratio of 75% while renewables participate only at 18%. From this, we can conclude that the housing sector is the right place for more intensive investment engagement to achieve the desired results in climate and energy policy. Synergy with other European Union policies, such as those aimed at producing renewable energy or raising energy efficiency in building, opens up a whole new perspective for the European economy, including labour and employment.  This all has the potential to launch a new investment cycle, create new jobs, from research and development, engineering, design to medium and small business that designs these systems, builds them and later maintains them. It is also necessary to enable the participation of as many citizens as possible, as producers and consumers, so that this investment potential is not intended for large energy companies.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: – Mr President, while I respect the outcome of the UK referendum I still believe that many people were not given adequate information, especially when it comes to energy. This week we are voting on two reports on EU guidelines for renewables. Meanwhile, data highlights the fact that the UK is failing to achieve our 2020 renewable targets. Post Brexit, the UK has a big decision to make: do we want to follow ambitious EU targets creating a strong economy and a safer environment for future generations, or do we want a race to the bottom and the scrapping of renewable targets to massage big business? I call on the UK Government and our Secretary of State for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy, Greg Clark, to clarify the Government’s position ahead of Brexit negotiations. What is it, Greg: a race to the bottom, or a future for our young people?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, let me begin by informing the House that at these times the pine-covered island of Thassos is on fire. I convey the cry of anguish of the residents and local authorities who are calling, Mr Cañete, for the immediate activation of the European Union's civil protection mechanism in order for the other countries of the Union to provide firefighting aircraft to assist the Greek canaries in extinguishing the fire in Thassos. Mr President, further deregulation of the energy market does not help citizens but multinationals. This was demonstrated by the scandalous experience of liberalising the electricity market in Greece which is now very expensive. All this despite promises, Mr Cañete, here last January to tackle the major problem of overtaxation of electricity in Greece, whose citizens, because of the memorandum, are forced to no longer buy expensive heating oil and burn what they find, resulting in smog which leads thousands of our fellow citizens to death every year.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). Mr President, I would agree that the Mediterranean countries are really vulnerable to fires. Yesterday it was Cyprus, today it is Thassos but also other areas of the Mediterranean, and it is a necessary necessity for the European Union to assist by all means in this direction not only to extinguish fires but to repair the damage.  Certainly, energy issues are of the utmost importance to the European Union, member countries and consumers. And left-wing Members who refuse on these issues do not care more about consumers and do not realise that the redesign of the energy market will bring about greater energy efficiency, which also means reducing costs for consumers. But the key words here are greater energy efficiency but also energy security. Energy security, Commissioner, and I am addressing you, if that is really our objective, saying that we must turn to those countries that have potential for future energy support from the European Union. The Eastern Mediterranean is being offered in this direction and I will invite you to take the initiative to make Cyprus a coordinating energy centre and hub. Convergence of all countries and forces in the region so that Europe can truly become dependent, through this factor of providing energy wealth, through a Member State of the European Union. At the same time, however, I would like to stress that for isolated countries, and particularly island regions which the single internal energy market may not touch because of interconnection, there must be other support and support. I would like to end, Mr President, by stressing that these countries, particularly in the Mediterranean, have comparative advantages in terms of renewable energy sources.

name: Martina WERNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is high time for a European electricity market design. In recent years, an incredible amount has changed in the energy and electricity sectors. The electricity market design must therefore be made more flexible. With the overall good development of renewables and their steadily growing share in the energy mix, the face and conditions of the energy market are changing rapidly: the weight is shifting from central to decentralised organisation and, above all, to the citizens as consumers and also as producers. In June, we here in Parliament decided that the share of renewables should be at least 30% by 2030. We must not stifle this development under any circumstances. In view of very different developments in the Member States, we should also be careful not to prevent the respective measures to promote renewables by Means of European regulations, and that is why we should not exclude the still necessary subsidisation of renewable energies. This also applies to long-term guaranteed purchase prices.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, energy security, an Energy Union – these were big topics that we were discussing here in Parliament around a year ago. Now we have bigger issues to work on, like Brexit, the migration crisis, etc. But strategically speaking, the energy sector remains one of the key issues for the future of the European Union. For the future of our economy – because cheaper, clean and reliable energy resources are a precondition for the good development of our economies. That is why I very much welcome the reports, especially the reports of Mr Langen. Regarding this report there is one key issue, and the issue was debated here. The energy mix and most of the issues concerning energy are considered to be the responsibility of the Member States, but efficient solutions, the efficient use of resources, the design of grids, and consumption and production do not respect the borders of states. That is why we should increasingly take this fact into account, otherwise we will not reach an effective solution at the European level. That is why I call on the Member States to look at the issues that will allow us to efficiently use our resources and create the conditions that will lead to affordable energy supplies. Especially, we should allow a better use of price signals to ensure capacity is available; we should strengthen the role of ESRA in order to promote regional development; and obviously we should support R&D because for the better use of renewable energies in particular we need to work on the storage of energy. I believe that better rules will ensure that more private investment is made in this market and that is why I call on the Member States to look at this issue as a priority.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – I, too, welcome both important reports, as well as the Commission's reports, which talk about the regulation and design of the energy market, as well as, of course, heating and cooling in Europe and the strategy in this area. We are changing the documents at a time when we are talking about the Energy Union on the one hand and, on the other, we also committed ourselves to the environmental objectives in Paris last year, and it is these two reports that are going in the right direction. They are heading in a direction where, on the one hand, energy efficiency is encouraged and energy efficiency is the alpha and omega of everything that we need to talk about in the energy itself. There are a lot of things we can do with our regulations, a lot can be sorted out by the states themselves, and a lot of these things can also be regulated at the local level. Like many of you, I have experience of local activity. I was mayor of a municipality that was the first to be declared the most energy-efficient municipality in Slovenia, and from my own experience I can tell you how many things can be arranged at the local level. In the case of renewable energy sources, it is also necessary to talk about water potential. Again in Slovenia, in the country from which I come from, we have placed five hydroelectric power plants in the regional environment, which now produce 7% of electricity in Slovenia. Green energy, jobs and, at the same time, flood protection. So in these reports, as we say in Slovenia, there is a lot of salt, so it is right to take them seriously, take them at European level and on the principle of subsidiarity, taking on their share of the responsibility of the state as well as the local community.  And only together will we succeed in this area.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the international scenario shows that energy security helps to consolidate the political independence of the Member States. This scenario cannot be separated from that relating to the efficient use of energy and the reduction of CO2 emissions, the energy resilience of individual countries... (The President cut the speaker off.)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the international scenario shows that energy security helps to consolidate the political independence of the Member States. This scenario cannot be separated from that relating to the efficient use of energy and the reduction of CO2 emissions, the energy resilience of individual countries and the fight against energy poverty. We must therefore encourage and pursue a dialogue aimed at improving the way in which energy change processes are carried out.  I agree with the rapporteurs that the objective is urgent, binding, but above all geopolitical, if only we consider that the energy markets still remain highly regionalistic, on the basis of the principle of national responsibility for the energy mix. This different management of sovereignty is an important part of the challenges facing Europe in the energy sector that ultimately needs... (The President cut the speaker off.)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Let me just say that it was impossible for the majority of colleagues to follow what you have said. It was just too fast for the interpreters and they are really doing their very best, I know that.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the creation of a single energy market that ensures security of supply, advances clean generation and provides stable legal frameworks to promote investment is one of the biggest challenges in our Union. Achieving this goal is useful for citizens, first of all, as consumers, but also as entrepreneurs, and is useful for businesses and their competitiveness. It is also essential so that free competition can be talked about in the internal market. Right now, differences in energy prices between Member States are one of the main distortion factors. For these reasons, I stress that this objective is a priority and I recall that the foundations of our common cause, the credibility of our Union , of the European Union - begin with our ability to solve the general day-to-day problems affecting all Europeans. When we talk about fragmentation of the electricity market, we are talking about these kinds of problems.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the creation of the single energy market does not serve objectives other than those pursued in other areas, namely to defend the interests and profit-drive of the major European economic groups in the sector, to promote monopolistic concentration at European level. With more or less social and environmental flourishes, the legislative process that it does is to reproduce the specifications of these interests, whether at the level of ambitious integration of markets, or in terms of infrastructure development, the latter supported by instruments such as the Juncker Plan, which puts public resources in the pockets of large private economic groups, which start to control strategic infrastructure.  Only with democratic public control of the energy sector, which means public ownership and management of production and distribution companies, can we answer sharp questions such as energy efficiency, diversification, the advancement of renewables, security of supply, among others. Even the issue of interconnections should be considered in this context.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, what is set out in the report on the redesign of the energy market significantly limits the state's ability to regulate, for the benefit of its citizens, this very important issue of energy. At the same time, it enables the large companies involved in this subject to increase the price and to profit at the expense of the world. Energy is a very important commodity for modern society and must be the property of all people in the quantity required and at low prices. In order to do this, the action must be controlled and determined by the State. Otherwise, we will have the creation of monopolies and exploitation by multinational companies. People will suffer, just as they are currently in Greece, which, unfortunately, they do not tell you. They are hiding it because they do not want to cause problems in the European Union.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, heating and cooling represent the largest share in the EU’s energy demand. If you want that demand not to ruin the climate goals we set, we will have to solve the existing problems. As an example, two thirds of the EU’s buildings were built when energy efficiency requirements were non-existent, and nearly half of buildings have individual boilers that were installed before 1992.  That is why improving the heating and cooling sector all around the EU is going to play a crucial role in reaching the goals of the Paris Agreement but, in order to achieve that, EU Member States should be pushed to do more, to do something concrete, to support concretely innovation, energy prosumers, households, local enterprises that are constantly monitoring their energy consumption , that produce energy they sell back to the grid. If there is concrete support for these rising stars of the European Union, then maybe we can achieve the goal that we set; otherwise it is just empty talk which will end in a surprise.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I am sorry I have only just come in because I was in a bus to Strasbourg for over three hours – an indication I suppose of a waste of energy, in some respects. I would like to compliment the Commissioner, who has done tremendous work in this whole area as we build towards a future European Energy Union. Every aspect of it is very important. I was fortunate to be in Paris at the COP 21 and I will be in Morocco at the end of November. But implementation is crucial, and heating and cooling has a huge part to play. Sometimes it is almost the silent solution that people are not aware of, but there is growing awareness of it now and I saw it in my own constituency recently, where people are clubbing together to ensure that they can put in heating and cooling systems. I think that, once we bring the public with us, they will be very pleased to be part of this whole process, because everybody now, I think, is clued in to the need to limit the damage being done by climate change and to play their part, and this is one aspect of it.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: – Mr President, I welcome today's debate on energy in the EU, particularly on heating and cooling. In the EU, as in the Czech Republic, a large proportion of buildings suffer from energy waste, which is due to their age and outdated heating technologies. We are wasting heat, while almost 11% of EU citizens suffer from energy poverty. We therefore need measures and additional investment in research into modern saving technologies, which will reduce the total cost of heating households and increase energy efficiency at all basic stages of energy use.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I want, first of all, to thank all of you for your comments and for this fruitful and timely discussion. I am very glad that broadly, we are following the same line towards achieving our 2030 and COP 21 targets. Here in the debate I think there is full support for the two reports in the House. Naturally, some points have been raised on which there are elements of divergence, mainly in relation to capacity support schemes: this is an extremely difficult issue and it will be one of the most important elements of the package that the Commission will propose. The electricity market design proposal is one of the key pieces of legislation in the Union action plan, and probably the most difficult to engineer. We have a unique opportunity, we have made progress with the previous packages but here we have an opportunity in a different scenario because, as Mr Kelly pointed out, in COP 21, in Paris, we assumed very ambitious objectives. The European Union has a very ambitious renewables target and to achieve that we have to change absolutely the functioning of our market and the integration of renewables and, as Mr Turmes says, it is a big challenge. We can discuss many of the elements, but the main purpose of the new package will be to put the consumers in the centre: consumers must be at the centre of the market design because they are prosumers, they redistribute the generation, and this is about the use of renewables. It is a different market from the old decentralised market, and the current market is not fit for purpose. So it is a very challenging exercise and I appreciate all the comments made here. For sure, the Commission is going to present a package. It is not only about market design, it covers energy efficiency, the energy performance of buildings and a renewables directive. And on all of these proposals we must follow the same logic. The logic is that we have to follow a pattern of decarbonisation of our economies: that is the message from Paris. Renewables have come to stay, and we have to develop them, and we have to make the market fit for purpose. So, as I stated earlier, and as I can confirm again, both reports and the rich debate we have just had constitute a very solid basis from which we can get to work on the whole range of issues that will be coming up in the next weeks and months. In the context of decarbonising of our economies, there is no doubt that the heating and cooling sector is an absolute game changer when it comes to security, economic growth and reaching our climate and energy targets. We have to dedicate lots of time to this sector, and it is very important that work in this sector – work on energy efficiency, making the best use of the EPC (Energy Performance Certificate) and the future EPC that is also coming – will be one of the priorities of the Commission.
