I also note with satisfaction that this House as a whole is committed to achieving a truly integrated and flexible market, providing the right signals for investment where they are most needed. The market does not currently give signals for investment in the right places – that is for sure – and Mr Turmes is right to point out the problem, but probably I have more trust than he does in the reform of the emission trading system, and the emission trading system is before this House. At the moment you are discussing it, and I think that the changes that have been introduced will be effective in the future. I am not as pessimistic as Mr Turmes is. I count on all of you to back these reports because they are excellent reports and they give a solid basis for the work the Commission has to do in the coming months. We want to deliver the whole package this year, as set out in the action plan. Next year we will come along with targets for CO2 emissions: we will have, I am sure, a very fruitful discussion with this Parliament, and I am sure, when I see the spirit and the concerns of the MEPs who have intervened, that there will be a high degree of consensus between the Commission and Parliament on developing a market that functions , a market which is fit for the targets we have in our climate policy, and a market which brings us affordable, secure and clean energy. On that we all agree, and now we have to put all the tools in place to achieve it.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: Rapporteur. – Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. When I listen to these speeches from my colleagues, I must say that I am afraid not to make a two-way error. Namely, the electricity market is a market linked to the fact that electricity, or electricity, can be transferred over long distances, that is, it can be a single market. On the other hand, when it comes to heat, these heat transfer distances are much smaller, i.e. we can talk about local markets here. It can be a few, a dozen or even a few dozen kilometres, although not too far away, that is, we can talk about local markets, and I would ask you to take these issues into account here with these laws, so as not to treat these markets equally.  On the other hand, with regard to the issue of heating and cooling, I must admit that, indeed, when it comes to the Paris issue of protecting our climate, COP 21, I believe that the largest reserves (although this is probably immolable, because this is not in the ESA) are in the thermomodernisation of buildings – that is two thirds. Just take to the streets in Brussels and see how poorly this isolated city is, let alone talk about the many settlements and cities in Central and Eastern Europe. These are the largest reserves that can be used as soon as possible. One more thing I have to say, also in terms of renewable energy, is the fastest way to put it in there and use it, in the thermomodernization of buildings, by warming buildings, but new solutions, further technical solutions are needed. We are talking at other meetings here about reindustrialisation. It must be said that there are renewable energies such as geothermal energy, such as energy obtained from heat pumps, and that is also what we need to focus on, because this is the future in the future industrialisation, and this proposal must be put forward.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday, 13 September 2016. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. – The creation of a single EU energy market is one of the EU's top priorities, not only in the field of energy itself, but also in terms of increasing the competitiveness of the EU as a whole, increasing resilience to various crises and meeting the EU's 2030 climate change and energy targets. The proper model and properly implemented European energy market have the potential to substantially strengthen Europe's energy security and independence, in particular from the monopoly external suppliers on which the Union is still dependent. In order to create a genuine energy market, the remaining EU energy islands need to be abolished urgently and integrated into Europe's energy networks in the fields of gas and electricity. The development of a new electricity market model requires greater health of electricity and gas systems, which will allow the EU and individual Member States to become more resilient and respond more quickly and more effectively to supply disruptions.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – Heating and cooling consume half of the EU’s energy. What is shocking, however, is the fact that around 84% of this is still generated by fossil fuels. Bottom line – we are still far off our aims and targets. Heating and cooling have a direct and important impact on the EU economy. For this reason, and also due to its size, we need to discuss and address the sector’s competitiveness, decarbonisation and energy security. Their direct impact on our citizens and our households means that affordability and energy poverty are essential topics that need to be addressed, as do the geographical, economic and climate differences among our Member States. Currently, heating and cooling are produced and consumed locally within a fragmented European market. Consumers need to be at the heart of a strategy for heating and cooling. They need to be empowered to participate and have control over their demand. Moreover, the reality of Southern European countries need to be taken into account, particularly where Member States like Malta require extensive infrastructural changes to adopt and implement the proposed strategy.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. The European Union spends 59% of its total natural gas consumption and 12% of its oil consumption on heating and cooling, while every 1% increase in energy efficiency reduces natural gas imports by 2.6%. The EU will therefore pay particular attention to the development of a heating and cooling strategy in order to achieve the climate targets set and reduce its dependence on energy suppliers.  The heating and cooling of our buildings consumes nearly 35% of our total energy consumption, but with serious renovation work this could be significantly reduced. The stock of walls and single-layer windows with no proper insulation remains high. To this end, the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive has been established, which sets mandatory minimum energy efficiency criteria for new investments. In the case of industry, lower emissions can be achieved by insulation and efficiency gains, as heating to the right temperature is often an integral part of the production process. Nevertheless, the aim is to decarbonise processes as fully as possible. At the same time, in the case of processes at really high temperatures, heating with electricity from renewables cannot be the solution, so fossil fuels are needed. The EU's priority is to make the most of the resulting excess heat, or even cold excess. Finally, it is worth highlighting the role of LNG import terminals as an important source of district cooling.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. – If there is a sector that requires strategic planning, that is the energy. The development of conventional sovereign resources, the need to ensure an affordable supply to industry and households, public control over common energy, the energy transition to an environmentally sustainable model... These are all objectives which the market is unable to develop, something that the Union implicitly recognises by simultaneously promoting to the privatisation and liberalization of the energy sector a regulation which, however, only strengthens the privileges of energy oligopolies over consumers. The Langen report is but one more rhetorical piece in the same direction.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – A new concept of the electricity market must promote a safe, sustainable and efficient electricity supply that takes into account the dynamics of the relationship between renewable and conventional energy generation. Price volatility is a signal for accelerating reforms in the electricity market and an important element in finding solutions at European level for the construction of future interconnections, LNG terminals and energy storage capacities. I stress that conventional generation remains essential for maintaining security of energy supply, which the new design of the electricity market must take into account in order to ensure a good functioning. The use of national energy resources, the exploitation of hydraulic energy in the case of Romania, high-efficiency gas and coal-fired power plants, benefiting from the latest technologies, can make an essential contribution to the unlocking of the European energy market, decarbonisation and security of supply. I also consider it essential to introduce a market-based capacity remuneration mechanism that eliminates the gap between technological costs and market revenues, in order to integrate low-carbon investments into the market, ensure security of supply and reduce risks for investors.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – In a world in transition a new model of the energy market is needed and the European Union must lead this shift towards clean energy. It is time to phase out fossil fuels and give more weight to renewable energy, key to energy independence, diversification and security. All this goes through a safe market for new investors. In this connection, some States such as Spain have tarnished the legal certainty of any investment in renewable energy through a battery of retroactive regulations that has sown any investment in renewables with uncertainty, while increasing the burning of coal by 24% and triggering its CO2 emissions, seriously compromising compliance with climate agreements. In four years Spain has lost 35,000 skilled jobs and the photovoltaic energy sector, in which it was a world leader. At the same time, national coal is subsidised with the approval of the Commission and self-consumption is jamted with the sun tax. These and other issues, such as subsidies disguised as capacity payments for fossil and nuclear power generation, are the big issues that the new energy market must address.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. Heating and Cooling is a matter of primary importance to the EU, since it is responsible for 50 % of total energy consumption in Europe and part of it is poorly used or wasted. Reducing waste, producing heat with cogeneration plants and thermally isolating buildings are all actions that could bring enormous benefits to the EU and its citizens, as well as facilitating the achievement of Europe's commitments at COP21 in Paris. On the one hand, consumers would be able to save on the cost of their bills, and on the other, Europe could reduce its energy dependence on exporting countries. It is also necessary to promote the use of insulating technologies and materials, in particular in the renovation of old or energy-efficient buildings, both for public and private structures. Finally, it is important to remember the benefits that a sharp decrease in energy consumption for heating and cooling could bring to the environment, allowing citizens to live in healthier, cleaner and safer environmental environments.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on the report by Rosa D'Amato on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development on the implementation of the thematic objective "Improving the competitiveness of SMEs" (Article 9(3) of the Common Provisions Regulation) (2015/2282 (IN I)) (A8-0162/2016), – the report by Ramon Luis Valcércel Siso on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development on Cohesion Policy and Research and Innovation Strategies for Smart Specialisation (RIS3) (2015/2278 (INI)) (A8-0159/2016), – is the report by Iskra Mihaylova on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development on European Territorial Cooperation - Best Practices and Innovative Measures (2015/2280(INI)) (A8-0202/2016) and – the report by Mercedes Bresso on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development on the EU Strategy for the Alpine Region (2015/2324(INI)) (A8-0226/2016).

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my fellow Members and shadow rapporteurs with whom I worked productively during the negotiations.  The report that we adopted in the REGI Committee is an implementation report, aimed at analysing 'holistically' the various aspects relating to the implementation of Thematic Objective 3, namely the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises in the new programming.  As many as 23 million small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe (i.e. companies with fewer than 250 employees) account for around 99% of all enterprises, making a fundamental contribution to development, social cohesion, innovation and the creation of high-quality jobs and producing over 100 million jobs and income. In Europe, small and medium-sized enterprises are very diverse: the number of micro-enterprises (i.e. less than ten employees) operating both in traditional sectors and at start-up level is increasing. Today they are 93% of over 22 million small and medium-sized enterprises. In the current programming, the funds have doubled compared with the old one, but the large amount of funding – EUR 64 billion to be 140 billion – is a necessary but not sufficient condition for dealing with the many difficulties faced by our businesses on a daily basis.   First of all, we must say that the economic crisis and austerity policies have stifled domestic demand. Secondly, the bureaucratic and regulatory environment is a real jungle that actually makes it impossible to invest.  In the report we have stressed the importance of public procurement being organised in a transparent and innovative way. I therefore welcome the procurement directive and the single European tender document, which should considerably reduce the administrative burden on small and medium-sized enterprises.  At the same time, we must be vigilant, and I call on the Commission and the Member States to be vigilant, both on the backlog of payments and on whether the late payment directive is properly implemented. We absolutely cannot afford our small and medium-sized enterprises to be discouraged from participating in projects and programmes because of a lack of confidence in the system. (The President cut the speaker off.)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Ms D’Amato, please try to speak more slowly. There are a few languages in which we are used to listening a bit more slowly than in Italian. Colleague Caputo had the same issue. You are used to speaking very fast, you think very fast, but it needs to be interpreted, and some languages take the interpretation via another interpretation, so please slow down so that we can understand what you have to say.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Rapporteur. We must therefore be vigilant – and I call on the Commission to be vigilant – and we must also point out the importance of access to credit. Small and medium-sized enterprises, and micro in particular, have paid for the credit crunch and often find it very difficult to get banks to open credit lines. The risk is to put a worse piece of the hole if financial engineering is used to provide them with high-risk products. If we add to this the delays in cohesion policy, the over-regulation, the state aid regulations, we understand how complex and urgent it is to help our businesses. What do we propose? An integrated regional and European policy process, focusing on specific sectors, such as manufacturing, new technologies, sustainable construction, green vehicles and smart grids. We must, while respecting the territorial specificity of each region, promote the principles of the circular economic package, with the objective of sustainable economic development and paying particular attention to the promotion of green jobs.   A greener value chain, including refrabrication, repair, maintenance, recycling and eco-design, can offer considerable business opportunities to small and medium-sized enterprises.  The supply of energy at low cost is essential: European companies have the highest energy cost in the world and a decisive process of decarbonisation and self-production of energy must be proposed. In the light of the current migration crisis, small and medium-sized enterprises can offer an innovative opportunity for the integration of refugees entering the Eu ropean Union labour market.  Our small and medium-sized enterprises must be more glocal, as they say, but their internationalisation process should be based on corporate social responsibility.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner Creu, you know that some of the European Commission's axes of action in its current mandate are those relating to economic growth on the one hand and also on the creation of quality jobs, on the other hand. The Commission at the time launched a tool based on so-called strategies for smart special planning. But what is this about smart specialization strategies? You will see: they consist of the application of innovation, technological development and also research to the economic and productive reality of the regions, once they have been able to identify their strengths and also their weaknesses. The so-called RIS3s are therefore designed on the basis of operational programmes, which, on the other hand, obliges regions to develop their ex ante strategies, because otherwise it would be entirely impossible for them, the regions, to be able to access the funds. In addition, we will also say that these strategies have a marked participatory character. They involve citizens, companies, universities and, of course, public administrations. We in Parliament and in the Committee on Regional Development draw up a report which aims, inter alia, to encourage the Commission to continue forward with these strategies. We will say about this report which is the first to deal with this issue in this legislature and here in this Parliament. We will also say that the development of it has had the proposal of various associations, many of them, specialized in this sector, as well as with a very broad consensus of the members of the Commission, already referred to, of Regional Development; because I will tell you that at the time it was presented, the vote yielded the following result: 33 votes in favour, only 3 against and, in addition to all this, the same report has been enriched through a series — important in its number but, above all, important in its content — of amendments, up to a total of 20. I would like to stress about the content of this report, on the one hand, the need for the European Union to intensify all possible efforts to achieve that economic growth, which is smart, sustainable and also inclusive. I would also like to stress the importance of research, technological development and innovation being one of the investment priorities for the Regional Development Fund to make them the real basis from which to strengthen competitiveness and also quality job creation. There is also a need for analysis of the capacities, assets, competences, of each region and that new business opportunities can be opened up in this way. I would also like to stress that greater cooperation between regional authorities, as well as between transnational cooperation programmes, is needed to avoid duplication , I conclude, Mr President - as well as the establishment of a national observatory that can ensure stronger indicators. And I conclude by asking, and taking advantage of the Commissioner's presence, what problems have been encountered in relation to these strategies, not only in relation to their design and implementation, but also in relation to their evaluation.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, today I present the discussion approved by the European Parliament's Committee on Regional Policy on one of the two objectives of cohesion policy– European territorial cooperation or well-known INTERREG programmes. The report covers several key themes: good practices, including innovative contributions to the Europe 2020 strategy and territorial cohesion, simplification of the implementation of territorial programmes and future development recommendations. In this context, I would like to point out that cross-border and transnational cooperation has achieved over the years good practices in the field of better connectivity and accessibility, knowledge transfer and innovation, tackling environmental challenges, increasing administrative capacity in health, education, employment and labour mobility, and creating new partnerships. At the same time, the report points out that interreg's budget of around EUR 10 billion represents only two per cent and eight-tenths of the cohesion policy budget and unfortunately does not meet the major challenges facing European territorial cooperation. The report notes with concern the late adoption of interreg programmes and urges the Commission and the Member States to mobilise their efforts to implement them successfully. The Commission, the Member States and the managing authorities are called upon to establish structural and appropriately organised monitoring systems and evaluation plans with a view to better assessing and disseminating knowledge of interreg's achievements. The report encourages the use of INTERREG programmes in response to the challenges of overcoming the refugee crisis, as well as the exchange of good practices between local and regional authorities in border areas, including third countries, through macro-regional strategies.  The report also notes the important role played by INTERREG programmes in enhancing the innovation potential of regions by promoting synergies between smart specialisation strategies and the development of innovation networks. The need to establish joint research programmes, joint research infrastructure, partnerships and cooperation networks is underlined. Calls for synergies between Horizon 2020, the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the European Structural Investment Funds to focus on increasing the quantity, quality and impact of research and innovation investments. Financial instruments must be an integral part of INTERREG programmes by complementing grants. The report also notes the role of European territorial cooperation groups in promoting European territorial cooperation. Calls on the committees and the Member States to take full advantage of the opportunities provided by INTERREG in order to facilitate cross-border labour mobility by adapting, if necessary, the administrative and social regulatory framework. Interreg programmes should, while respecting agreed priorities as well as complementing other appropriate funding, support migration challenges and promote effective integration policies.  In this regard, the report underlines the possibilities of European territorial cooperation and its potential, which can be developed in future territorial cooperation programmes and underpin future cohesion policy based on the needs of the specific territory.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, cohesion policy, which we are debating today with these 4 reports, is one of the few instruments that are firmly on the side of citizens, students, workers and businesses. The resources at its disposal are resources that fall entirely on the territories and remain today one of the few sources of investment throughout the European Union, particularly at local level. The role of the regions and local authorities is important for cohesion policy, just as it is fundamental in the strategy for the Alpine macro-region, which my report, in particular, refers to.  The EUSALP strategy offers the countries of the region – from this very large region – an opportunity to invest in joint projects with a European impact, not only regional, and also to develop new forms of multi-level governance, originating from the regions and implemented with the help of the European institutions. I am therefore convinced that the role of regions and local authorities must be strengthened in the strategy. As I wrote in the report we voted on: the regions and local authorities will have to be fully involved in the management of the strategy if we are to achieve results. We also know how important it is that this strategy should not overlap with existing interregional and cross-border cooperation, but that it should be able to provide added value and complement the experiences that have already been undertaken. Above all, it is a question of addressing objectives common to the entire Alpine and Pre-Alpine area, but with repercussions for the whole of Europe – this is the great area of rebalancing in southern Europe. What is happening in this region is important, as we know, for the whole Union.  In line with the major European objectives of Europe 2020 – in the areas of sustainable development, the environment and energy – the design and implementation of projects with a macro-regional dimension should also be facilitated through this strategy. The EUSALP strategy really wants to be a useful tool for this.  It will therefore be important for the strategy to serve as a new support tool for economic development, growth and employment in these areas, not only in traditional sectors such as tourism and food and wine – which nevertheless remain fundamental – but also and above all in more innovative sectors. What will be important will be the interaction between large urban areas, peri-urban and rural areas with mountain areas, which will make it possible to determine the success of this strategy, but above all the economic recovery of these areas.  There are unused or poorly used resources just waiting to be revitalized. One of our proposals is to create an investment platform for the entire Alpine and Alpine region, which will enable public and private funding to be mobilised, including through the EIB, the opportunities offered not only by cohesion policy but also by EFSI.  However, we cannot think about the development of these territories until we are able to connect them to the rest of the world. There are still too many dark areas in these regions, in particular, where the Internet connection is weak or, moreover, absent. We need new solutions which, combined with the traditional ones, will enable those who really want to do business or simply contribute to the development of these areas, to be able to do so on an equal footing with competition.  In essence, we must make these areas attractive, a pole of attraction for young people, with opportunities and tools. We also reiterate in the report that the majority of the major infrastructures provided for in the TEN-T plan, these axes, will then have to be linked to widespread, efficient and sustainable local infrastructure. In short, it will not be the solution to all problems on its own, but it is a unique opportunity for the macro region.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, hello, I am very happy to be with you again today in plenary. I would like to begin by warmly thanking the rapporteurs: Mrs Mihaylova, Mrs D'Amato, Mrs Bresso and Mr Valcárcel, and, of course, the European Parliament's Committee on Regional Development for these four excellent reports which bring to the heart of our discussion both the support of cohesion policy for smart growth and territorial cooperation and for the strategy for the Alpine region. Given that, as you know, I only have five minutes to talk about these broad topics, I'm going to try to get right to the point. With regard to Mrs D'Amato's report on improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, the European Commission welcomes and shares the European Parliament's vision that operational programmes are currently much more focused on strategic priorities and, especially when aiming at innovation, they play a key role in creating high-quality jobs. Support for small and medium-sized enterprises, including start-ups, must indeed consider support mechanisms for entrepreneurial skills, as well as a range of external services for the benefit of small and medium-sized enterprises in order to relaunch, develop and innovate in many regions. At the same time, I agree with you that we need to ensure that these mechanisms are easily accessible to small and medium-sized enterprises. That is why, as you know, we have taken a number of measures to simplify the rules, and the results of the Working Party on Simplification, which is considering the support of small and medium-sized enterprises, will be seen at the end of September. We are trying to introduce some recommendations from this financial cycle, in particular, on e-cohesion and simplified costs, to make the lives of beneficiaries much easier. You know very well that it is not easy for us to find this balance between the need to simplify the rules and the need to know and have effective control over how European taxpayers' money is spent. The European Commission also notes the proposal to create a participatory platform to ensure the dissemination of the results of small and medium-sized enterprises' projects. I would like to point out that there is already a special page on the European Commission's Open Data Platform website where all projects financed by European money, including those of small and medium-sized enterprises in each country and in each region, are presented. With regard to Mr Valcárcel's report on research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation, I would, of course, welcome the European Parliament's strong support for smart specialisation in cohesion policy. I thank Mr Valcárcel for his presentation, as well as for your specific question. Indeed, the most powerful challenges are when it comes to implementation. Our challenge now is to ensure the implementation of these strategies on the ground, and I fully agree with your report, which underlines the need for better coordination of programmes and to establish collaborative platforms and partnerships, as well as to promote collaboration at all levels: intra-regional, inter-regional, cross-border and transnational. The Commission will continue to support these processes, for example through the Smart Specialisation Platform which provides extremely valuable support to the regions in the development and implementation of these strategies. From this point of view Spain, through the Seville Institute, makes an important contribution to the Member States and the regions. In addition, of course we will ensure that European regions take advantage of the potential to combine cohesion policy funding with other European Union instruments, such as Horizon 2020 and the investment plan, the strategic investment fund, what we already call, generically, the Juncker plan. In this respect, as you know, we have already published a guide to support those who wish to use these funds in a complementary way. Of course we will not stop here, we intend to develop other guides if necessary. These will be followed by exchanges of best practices in which I believe very much. It is a reality of life, after all, that some Member States and regions are more advanced, have more experience and more administrative capacity, and other Member States are still at the beginning of the road and I think we always have to learn from each other. With regard to Mrs Mihaylova's report on European territorial cooperation, this is a which is in my personal attention and DG REGIO. I would like to point out that, thanks to investment through the INTERREG programmes, we are now indeed seeing a real change for the better in terms of cross-border cooperation from research to transport and environmental protection. Basically, I visited 25 countries during my two years in office and tried to visit a lot of objectives concerning cross-border cooperation. Of course, this tool can still be optimised and needs to be optimised in a constantly changing environment. I therefore very much appreciate this report on its own initiative. I want to congratulate you on this idea. In particular, I agree with your recommendations that encourage the joint establishment of integrated and sustainable territorial development strategies in border areas. A common strategy is essential for the efficient use of the two specific instruments, namely integrated territorial investment and community-led local development, which can play an important role in this. Unfortunately, we have some cross-border programmes blocked and we will certainly try together with those countries to unlock them in order to start these cross-border programmes. But, of course, on the other hand, we have cross-border regions that have made full use of this common development potential. I believe that your support is essential. I assure you that for me personally, at a time when many Member States want to build borders again, for me it is a priority to raise administrative barriers between Member States. With regard to Mrs Bresso's report on the European Union's strategy for the Alpine region, I would like to welcome the balanced and well-developed approach, which takes into account the effort and contribution of several specialised committees in the European Parliament. We have had the opportunity, as you know, to talk on several occasions about this strategy bringing together advanced countries, some of the most advanced countries in the European Union, but also non-member countries and poorer regions, as you have also pointed out. I fully agree with you that it is necessary to promote and align, coordinate the financing of cohesion policy, as well as other European Union funds and financial instruments. In addition, the launch of projects and actions at regional macro level is extremely important in order to fully exploit possible funding options and synergies within the strategy. As you know, the Commission has adapted the legal framework of cohesion policy so that programmes take into account the objectives and projects of macro-regional strategies. I would, however, like to point out that the Alpine strategy, like all other regional macro strategies (the Danube strategy, the Baltic area strategy, the Adriatic-Ionian strategy), this Alpine strategy belongs primarily to the Member States and, moreover, it was adopted as a result of the requests of these Member States. The European Commission will retain its role as facilitator. I welcome your idea of having this investment platform. We are partners in this idea of seeing to what extent we can combine European funds, structural funds with strategic funds for infrastructure projects, but also for less developed areas. The Commission retains this active role and we will be here if our work will bring added value, but, of course, we cannot do so as the Commission without an active partnership with the participating Member States and regions. I'm sorry I'm out of time, there are four reports. Thank you very much and I look forward to the debate in plenary.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, Commissioner, let me first thank the rapporteur on the Alpine strategy, Mercedes Bresso, and underline the quality of her report. It is in fact as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs that I have the honour and pleasure of intervening on this subject, even if, in my European constituency, far from the Alps, the highest mountain is Mont-Saint-Michel, which bravely rises to 80 metres in height. I have tried to highlight in this report for advice, with my colleagues, the peculiarities of the Alpine region and to make concrete proposals on employment. Above all, it is essential that our strategy focuses on strategic sectors and, to this end, we propose, among other things, the creation of regional research hubs by involving companies.  We must also encourage multi-training and training in line with the labour market. In particular, we can imagine specific training centres and a multilingual regional online employment centre.  Specific responses must also be given to the various challenges, such as seasonality and multiactivity. Finally, Mr President, I would like to point out that the free movement of people is a prerequisite for achieving the objectives of economic, social, territorial and environmental cohesion, particularly for cross-border workers.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, environmental issues are transversal to many disciplines. Just think of the relationship between biodiversity, tourism, agriculture, forest management and livestock farming, between pollution, industry, transport, energy and the circular economy.  In the macro-region, more attention needs to be paid to mountain areas, which are often neglected than urban areas, by reconciling the environment and economic and social development in the Alpine air, an area rich in natural resources, culture and traditions. The fight against climate change has positive repercussions in the Alpine areas because today we are unfortunately witnessing the reduction of glaciers and the torrential rains that cause landslides and floods. It is essential to fight the abandonment of the territory because the garrison is an important tool against hydrogeological failure.  In this area, and not only, Europe should show greater flexibility, not least because bureaucratic rigidities are not adapted to these small realities. I congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Bresso, on her work and on having taken up many of the issues that we voted for by a large majority in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport, I am disappointed both with the method adopted by the rapporteur in drawing up the final report and with regard to some important content approved in the committees responsible for the opinion but not included in the final text.  With regard to the method, the rapporteur has decided that she does not want to include in the report anything as approved in the other committees, she felt that she wanted to reformulate everything independently. I believe that this does not respect the work done by each of us, which is shared between the various political groups for the reference committee. I therefore call on you to give serious consideration to the amendments that will be voted on tomorrow and which contain precisely the points from the texts of the various opinions and which have not been taken into account by the rapporteur.  In these amendments we have re-proposed issues such as the need to guarantee citizens' access to documents relating to publicly funded works, we have asked for priority to be given to public health and the environment on the basis of which access to documents can be guaranteed, and we have also asked that new transport infrastructure projects should not be started or financed until the existing infrastructure is fully exploited.  The Committee on Transport had also requested that infrastructure which involves an avoidable and disproportionate risk to the environment, natural resources or public health should not be financed. How can we not think, therefore, of Turin-Lyon, a work that has been constantly rejected and rejected by the local populations, never questioned and never taken into account in the final decisions. In the Committee on Transport, we called for public consultations to be promoted in order to respect the will of the citizens and not to create new major useless works which irreparably damage health and the environment and which fuel corruption and mafia infiltration.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. Mr President, I would like to thank the Agriculture is the basis for a vibrant Alpine region, as we know and appreciate it in many countries. Agriculture and forestry are thus also laying the foundations for the successful implementation of the EU strategy for the Alpine region. Only with functioning agriculture and forestry can we cultivate a cultural landscape, protect biodiversity and maintain an attractive habitat for our young families in order to prevent rural exodus.  As a result, we must be careful with our resources and protect the property of farming families. The Alpine strategy with the networked approach recognises the need to respond specifically to the needs of the regions. In this way, we strengthen crafts, tourism, mobility and preserve the Alpine region as a living, economic and recreational area.  I would like to thank all my colleagues, because together we have succeeded in taking up the essential key points for the further development of the Alpine region.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to thank Mrs Mihaylova very warmly for paying attention to European territorial cooperation with her report. European territorial cooperation is, in my opinion, the essence of what the European Union is. The history of European territorial cooperation is a success for all who demonstrate the value of working together across borders. This is a success for the beneficiaries, who have left behind thousands of projects and good practices.  Cross-border programmes are particularly important. They are proof of the importance of impact on the border areas of the European Union, as well as in third countries. It is still in the border areas that we need to build an adequate level of trust and partnership on each side of the border. Let us also remember that cross-border areas are peripheral areas that we should look at, deal with and support in particular.  We must also ensure that, after 2020, European territorial cooperation has a sufficiently high budget to increase the effectiveness and efficiency of these instruments. We also need more flexibility in the implementation of European territorial cooperation and, above all, more trust at every level of governance and implementation of European territorial cooperation.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, cohesion policy and, by implication, territorial cooperation are the visible hand of the single market, which aims to ensure a balanced and sustainable development of the regions of the European Union. It fosters economic integration in the countries of the European Union and allows for the improvement of the competitive position of regional economies by providing European public goods that the market cannot provide. Each European territory has its own role and can and must become a source of development in itself through a fair distribution of economic activities. Recent economic analyses confirm this approach through numerous studies demonstrating that geography matters and that regional policy can change things. An essential element for success is the involvement of national, regional and local governments in fundamental strategies and in the creation of networks that go beyond national physical and political boundaries. Even if there is no universal recipe for this cooperation and for regional development policy, principles such as partnership, transparency, subsidiarity and civil society participation combine harmoniously, and strengthening partnerships between the public and private sectors makes it possible to make decentralisation and active involvement of the whole society more efficient. On the other hand, the role of small and medium-sized enterprises which have generated 58 % of the added value in the sector should be emphasised.  In this context, I consider it essential to have effective cooperation between the Commission and the Member States to support entrepreneurial training projects among rural women and young people, SMEs that will contribute to job creation, the development of new services, as well as increasing incomes and avoiding depopulation of these areas. On the other hand, we must not forget that Europe's regions have to adapt to the pressures of the global economy. Climate change poses a threat to some sectors and an opportunity for others, and demographic change and an ageing population require new policies in the labour market. As long as the European Union has aspirations, it must also have an adequate cohesion policy to enable them to be fulfilled. One of the things we all aspire to is common progress in a reunified Europe. After all, it is our regions, areas and cities that make investments, implement national and Community policies and apply legislation in the European Union. Therefore, they must not remain out as mere spectators, but must be viable partners.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Mr. President, SMEs form the backbone of the European economy and strengthening their competitiveness is of utmost importance for economic growth and reducing unemployment. I have never heard of a politician who is against the growth of competitiveness, but the vast majority of them, with their ideas and moves, impede this process, because they place too much tax and administrative burden on entrepreneurs.  The over-regulation of the market to which it often resorts and this home can only impede small and medium-sized enterprises from growing them, just as high taxes from which oversized or even completely unnecessary public policies are financed. SMEs will be more competitive if the policy interferes less with their work and frees up space for them with a regulatory guillotine and a reduction in the tax burden. Therefore, I wholeheartedly support the REFIT program, which so far successfully removes regulatory barriers. Unfortunately, the establishment of the single market has not eliminated them in itself, but in many industries we have only added the European one to national regulation and thus actually increased the regulatory burden. I agree that we need to increase the absorption of funds, but we must bear in mind that micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, especially from newer Member States, often do not have the necessary capacity. Therefore, it is necessary to simplify the rules and procedures to make it easier for money to come to those for whom it is intended. Otherwise, it will be used mainly by companies from more developed regions and Member States, which is in no way in line with our cohesion objectives.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, for the European Liberals, SMEs have always been the key driver for the EU’s growth, development and job creation. In the EU we are dealing with about 23 million SMEs which make up around 99% of all businesses and generate two in three private-sector jobs. I believe these figures are more than enough to expect that the EU authorities make every effort to simplify common rules and measures, foster synergies of different programmes, boost diversification of sources for SMEs and strengthen policy coordination. Also, the cultural gap needs to be bridged between the Structural Fund procedures and SMEs’ daily business practices in different countries and the regions. The EU Cohesion Policy has never had an easy life. Since its inception, the criticism has been rather constant. However, we all know what a huge impact for growth and development the European Structural and Investment Funds had and have for many EU Member States. And again, to invite money is no longer an option. The only way to meet and empower this important EU investment instrument is to think, talk and act for effective and innovative employment of public resources, which would bring maximum impact and added value. Still too much of EU cohesion money is deposited in the concrete; still too little is aimed at innovations.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done There is no doubt that these reports summarise important experience in the implementation of regional policy, but these must now be put into practice. This concerns issues of simplification for regional administrations, SMEs and smaller projects, closer cross-border and cross-cutting cooperation, greater decision-making powers on the ground and, ultimately, closer to the citizens.  Of particular importance, however, would be the end of unilateral austerity, because it is the greatest threat to cohesion and public investment policy. And it is absurd to threaten to freeze structural funds when countries such as Portugal or Spain have little room for investment anyway. Finally, the massive cuts to the EU budget in 2017, particularly in the area of cohesion policy, jeopardise the success of all efforts to bring living conditions in Europe into line with living conditions. A new social pillar, a la Juncker, sounds good, but we must not cut back on the only existing instrument with which the EU pursues a policy of solidarity, namely cohesion policy.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this report should normally be aimed at promoting sustainable development in the Alpine region and it really lacks ecological ambition in terms of transport and the development of renewable energies. We will remain adamant about major infrastructure projects, and Lyon-Turin in particular. If our amendments are not accepted, we will refuse to adopt this report. We ask that it is no longer possible to launch an infrastructure project if there is already an infrastructure that is under-exploited, and this is the case for Lyon-Turin. In France itself, we have recently had confirmation from the Court of Auditors and by the president of SNCF, who believe that the Lyon-Turin is a total gabegie. Environmentalists have been fighting for years against Lyon-Turin, which is the six-times-dearest repetition of Perpignan-Figueras. The Perpignan-Figueras had already cost 25 million euros per kilometre; Lyon-Turin will cost 200 million euros! Today we see that the Perpignan-Figueras line is bankrupt and we discover in the sncf financial report that the passenger forecast has been overstated by 85% and that of freight by 92%. In the end, it is the taxpayers who pay the bill to the banks, while the European Union, France and Spain contributed 58% of the budget. We call for sound management of public funds, we are in support of the modal deferral, of course, immediate that will relieve the Alpine valleys of heavy truck pollution, but we propose cheaper and easier solutions to implement for which it is perfectly possible to use existing rail infrastructure.

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, cohesion or regional subsidy is too often a means to throw good taxpayers’ money after bad. In the real world, to help SMEs to deliver growth you have to make markets work and make them deliver high quality competitive products and services from satisfied, well—paid workers. You put the role of the market centre stage but only as a vehicle to deliver prosperity, not as an ideological end in its own right. Getting markets to operate in the general or public interest is one of the most vital, yet difficult, tasks of politicians. We have to recognise the massively damaging consequences of all cartels and oligopoly, and of private monopoly and state control – in short of cronyism at taxpayers’ expense. There is little or nothing in these reports which shows any understanding of this. What is required is not cronyism, but proper competition which is not rigged or manipulated. That has to mean lots of players in the market, none of whom is able to achieve dominance. Dominance does not just mean monopoly. It also means a small number of big players effectively operating as a cartel. As usual, the EU starts with worthy intentions but, because it does not understand the nature of the problem, it will waste money, achieve little and probably make the situation worse. That is why my country has voted to leave.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Last week, the European Court of Auditors published a not-too-surprising report on Moldova. In recent years, eur 780 million has gone up in smoke in that small country. Mr President, how can it be that a country that scores a big enough score on the corruption index every year is rewarded with millions of euros in money? And then we can talk about innovation strategies here, but let's look at how to be innovative in spending taxpayers' money and stop giving money to heavily corrupt countries. Because, every year, there are dozens of reports of tax money being tampered with without being penalised. And that is why, on behalf of the taxpayer, I ask you: when will this stop?

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, so-called economic cohesion within the Union exists only in the offices and corridors of the European institutions, but even this needs a lot of debate. Small and medium-sized enterprises should be the most important sector in which innovation should be supported and promoted. In fact, it is only thanks to this type of business that there is the current standard of living which, despite the huge differences from country to country, is much better than that of developing countries. We cannot talk about strategies that will create the basis of knowledge for sustainable growth and high-quality jobs when many of the Union's wrong policies have led to a fall in living standards, especially in the countries of the South, with underemployment and a minimum wage of hunger. In fact, agreements such as TTIP will be disastrous for small and medium-sized enterprises. The general direction is wrong. Again you will give grants on the basis of criteria that have little to do with the reality and needs of the market, with labyrinthine bureaucratic procedures, which will to a large extent be collected by the usual suspects. If you really want cohesion of the Union economy then we need to take action. Establish a single basic salary, establish uniform tax rates that are fair to all, and abolish subsidies to save resources to raise wages and make up for any tax losses. Rest assured that this will allow businesses to breathe and achieve a significant growth rate. However, in order to take such measures, the Union should be really interested in sound investment and the good of workers and self-employed people and not in serving the interests of capitalists and multinationals.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Mrs Bresso, for the good and, in my view, very successful cooperation on the report 'EU strategy for the Alpine region'. We have put forward a successful report and I am keen to raise a few points here today. Anyone who has studied this EUSALP report knows that this impact has on the habitats of 80 million people in 48 regions and in 7 countries. In my opinion, there is no room for left-green fantasies in a report with such a scope. The protection and sustainable management of our nature and environment are, of course, important and desirable; however, people must not fall by the wayside in pursuing this objective. The locals can enjoy an alpine landscape, however beautiful, but if they do not get a job on site or other circumstances force him to leave his home region, the price paid for nature and the environment is too high. That is why it is essential to enable the people of these regions to stay in their homeland. And this can only be achieved through support and investment: financial support for the economy, for more jobs, for cross-border transport, for the expansion of the Internet, for an economically strong Alpine habitat in which future generations should also be able to live and work.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Rapporteur Mihaylova on the final document on European Territorial Cooperation. In fact, we have achieved improvements in connectivity, mobility, accessibility, knowledge transfer, the creation of new partnerships and risk management in disaster responses.  Portugal was buffeted by fires and burned more than 100,000 hectares. In my region – Madeira, an outermost region – burned almost 6,000 hectares and the fire descended into the urban center of Funchal, consuming about 23 % of its territory. We have had 1,000 displaced and five hundred displaced, three people have died and we now have 23% of our territory in the capital of Madeira burned. The losses amount to EUR 61 million. 54% of the total burned area of the European Union was in Portugal. How long do you estimate the Commission will be necessary to help my country? I cannot fail to thank the countries that helped us – Italy and Spain, as well as Morocco and Russia. We will adopt this report calling for greater respect for regions, those that are structurally at a disadvantage, giving space to local and regional authorities through, in particular, ITI and CLLD. In this sense, I still do not understand the Commission's obstinacy in threatening Portugal with sanctions through European funds, which strongly affect the country and its regions.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased to speak, because the report on the Alpine strategy – and I thank the rapporteur, Mrs Bresso – is a report that is attentive to two major issues. , if you like, and, in between, this extraordinary Alpine area, useful to the whole of Europe, but so fragile, so difficult. Think that only depopulation in those territories over the last ten to fifteen years is 40%.  It is an area which, if we do not have the attention due to the active infrastructure that produces wealth, well-being and development in the north and south of the Alps, attention to the environment, to everything we are introducing, those same infrastructures, when they cross that fragile region, become passive structures.  And where depopulation is due to a land that is difficult to work with, an area that is very difficult to develop – but at the same time a very important area – we find ourselves having to guarantee an income for those territories, so that in the future there is population, not depopulation.  The opportunity to populate those areas is given by a strategy such as the one we will approve tomorrow, which we are debating this evening, capable of providing an additional income to those territories, where depopulation is not due to the love that is lacking in relation to that land – which is there and is strong, love – but because it is impossible, in this way, in these conditions.  I occasionally hear about criminal infiltration – I use this term not to use very Italian terms. I believe that we should instead think about development, then there are the instruments, the people responsible for monitoring the success of development, but development is necessary.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: – Investment is the basis for growth and jobs, which is why the European Union is also investing billions in research and development. That's why we invest in opportunities for the future, but an investment in innovation doesn't automatically create a new job. This requires cooperation between industry, knowledge institutions, governments and social institutions. And that is exactly what we have in mind with these so-called smart specialization strategies. The experience with these strategies has so far been positive. That's very nice, but of course it can always be better. Therefore two points: First, not every region is the same. That is why I call on regions not to copy each other's success models. Assume your own strength. Start from your own capabilities and base the regional innovation strategy on it. Base them on the region's own specific forces and own specific needs. Secondly, smart specialisations can really give a huge boost to new innovations and economic growth in the regions. But it is important that the European Union, together with national authorities, also gives these local and regional partners sufficient financial resources to be able to invest on the basis of this smart specialisation strategy. Only in this way can we make a leap towards a stronger and more competitive Europe.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are wasting EUR 26 billion on building a new Turin-Lyons tunnel, instead of an existing network that is perfectly capable of dealing with commercial traffic. In Italy, almost EUR 6 billion has been wasted on building the Meuse, a system of mobile dams that does not serve to protect Venice from the waters, but has served to enrich the corrupt. Instead, only EUR 509 was found for the safety of the bell tower in Accumuli, a country of the Italian earthquake, which collapsed killing a family.  Our Alpine regions have not found the funds for years to secure rivers, mountains ravaged by speculation, and every year floods and landslides become increasingly catastrophic. Politicians visit the places of disaster and promise that it will never happen again and they know they are lying. All this will continue until we end the wretched policy of major useless works in order to allocate public money to the real common interest, which is the protection above all of the lives of citizens, territories and waterways.  That is why I call on you to vote for the amendments to the Bresso report which support the financing of transparent projects, the protection of public water sources, which must remain public, and against the absurdity and waste of Turin-Lyons.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Mr President, we will support the RIS3 report, but allow it, from this positive assessment, to provide some elements of implementation that we think are appropriate for the Commission to incorporate from the mid-term review. One: more region, less state, in the definition and management of programmes, more and better direct relationship between Commission and regions. Two: greater attention and priority to small-scale projects and actual penetration into the productive fabrics of each region, almost always defined by small and medium-sized enterprises. Three: attention to the risk of the gradual conversion of RIS3 into a mere expectation of higher revenues that Member States wish to recover from the European Union budget. Evaluation and accompaniment mechanisms must therefore be strengthened. Four: new accents in the territorial and sectoral sense. Cities and metropolitan areas must assume an explicit and leading role. Emphasis should be placed on connecting regional programmes with central European strategies, in particular on energy transition, the circular economy and climate change. Five: specialization doesn't mean working solo. Relative innovation, useful contact of the most advanced regions with which they are trying to regain positions, should be a central element of the program. Only in this way will we prevent this programme from increasing the disparities between regions which still today negatively characterise the European Union. And six: caution in the introduction of new financial instruments, grants to loans, if we do not want to fall into the contradiction of making profitability a single criterion of a programme which must increasingly be the axis of a genuine European public policy aimed at reducing imbalances and economic convergence between its regions.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We are talking today about cohesion policy. This means that the EU wants to make up for economic imbalances between regions by means of subsidies. More than EUR 1 000 billion has already been redistributed since 1988, with EUR 350 billion to be added by 2020. I think it is a mockery that the European Union is now telling small and medium-sized enterprises that they want to support them with EUR 140 billion. It is these small and medium-sized enterprises, these SMEs, the backbone of our society. They only generate the funds that are subsequently redistributed, which are pulled out of their right pocket, in order to put them back into the left part of it. Let us stop the redistribution! Let us stop this cohesion policy! Let us stop them now and let us ensure that SMEs – especially SMEs – are freed from unnecessary fiscal and bureaucratic ballast – this could be a real added value.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: Mr President, elected from the south-east of France, I am very committed to the preservation of the second largest biodiversity basin in Europe, the Alpine region. For 25 years, I have defended people's quality of life and respect for the environment. I did not hesitate to denounce, as such, the Lyon-Turin line project. Although the European Union is funding this project at an undue cost, the Alpine strategy has the merit of defending sustainable forest and ecosystem management and cross-border cooperation in the management of climate and hydrogeological risks.  Similarly, the maintenance of crops and livestock in the mountains, the fight against rural exodus and the consumption of local products are a priority.  However, the European Union must respect the role of local authorities as well as international cooperation such as the 1991 Alpine Convention, which brings together several countries, including Switzerland, which is not in the Union. Finally, in a nutshell, let us remain vigilant in the face of the European Union's macro-regional integration strategies, which aim to eventually supplant the framework of national and local actions.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, today's joint debate on four reports on cohesion policy shows once again how diverse this central policy area of the European Union can be if the cohesion and structural policies are used in a targeted and for the benefit of the citizens.  I would like to refer once again to the report on European territorial cooperation. One of the principles of the European Union is freedom of movement – borders are no longer physically accessible to people, that is a good thing. They can come together, they can work together, and it is precisely in the border regions, which are often among the less developed regions within a Member State, that can be an advantage. The European Union has been supporting this for 25 years with the Interreg programme, but European territorial cooperation goes further.  There is a separate regulation for this, there are means for it, and we have also created the possibility, with the legal instrument of the European Association for Territorial Cooperation, for institutional cooperation to be carried out across existing national borders. Unfortunately, we have to note that often from the capitals, out of national selfishness, this work is blocked in the border regions, that one's own legal system, which is often not yet aligned with that of neighbouring countries, is held higher than territorial cooperation. I believe that we must continue to work on this, and I hope that, in the next cohesion report, territorial cooperation will once again be important – in the sixth cohesion break.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteurs, as well as the Commissioner for her contribution. I certainly welcome these reports we are discussing this evening and I want to concentrate on the reports on research and innovation and SMEs. Traditionally, we have focused our investment in cohesion funds on infrastructure, training and job creation, but we should not neglect the opportunities to also invest in research and development. One way of doing this would be to use structural funds and Horizon 2020 funds together. This does happen, but of course that are many obstacles in the way. We should be looking to make it easier to use those funds together; I think our own regulations can help in terms of improving simplification and bringing the regulations of the two funds closer together.  We should also be making it easier for SMEs to access structural funds. I am sure we have all heard complaints from SMEs in our own regions. Many SMEs do benefit from structural funds, through capital investments and through training programmes, etc., but again I believe we can do even more on this. Once again, our own regulations can help with that. I just wanted to conclude by saying that I understand that there are many critics of cohesion policy – and we have heard some critics here tonight – but I think sometimes we can be far too negative. Cohesion policy is a huge success story; you only have to look at the figures, the jobs created, the businesses created, in your own regions, to know it is a success story. I wish sometimes that colleagues would be more positive about it.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In today's cohesion debate, we are also discussing the future EU Alpine strategy. Two points are important to me, which I have successfully made through the ECR within the framework of the Family Party: demography and obstetrics. The future for the Alpine region is more than just economics and ecology. The third pillar is demographics, because the future needs growth, needs young people. Secondly, obstetrics: midwives are needed wherever offspring are to come. And this is not easy in alpine regions. That is what I have brought in for my family party. How topical this is is shown by the departure of many midwives and maternity wards, be it in Illertissen or In Sterzing.  I would also like to thank the friends of the South Tyrolean Civil Union. Your petition to preserve obstetrics in mountain regions underlines the need for my request. Let us fight together for midwives, we fight for the right of our mothers to safe birth!

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, Respected Madam Commissioner, respected colleagues, let me today emphasize a number of extremely interesting topics that we have on the agenda, when we talk about regional and cohesion policy, highlight the fact that our President of the Regional Development Committee, Ms. Mihaylova and our member Ms. Bresso offered excellent reports.  In particular, the topic that speaks about the competitiveness of medium and small enterprises is a topic that is extremely important to us, extremely important, especially for us liberals, but also as I hear about everyone else here in this aula. As rapporteur for the Adriatic-Ionian Macro-Region, I would like to take the opportunity to engage in a debate on the Alpine macro-region, i.e. the Alpine strategy of the European Union.  And that's where I want to highlight one global problem, a problem that's tied to all strategies. We have a historic three NO's. NOT for the new structure when we talk about macroregions, NOT for financing macro-regions, therefore not new funds, and we also have NO new regulations. Macroregions were formed, they started to work, and the Baltic and Danube rivers, the Adriatic-Ionian one is here and the Alpine one is here now. We still need to revise these historical three NE's and see how these macro-regions actually come to life to the end.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: GUE/NGL). Commissioner, in recent years there has been a great increase in inequalities, both social and regional, which undermines the cohesion of the European Union itself and causes an increasing number of citizens who do not see the European Union meeting their expectations, especially in the countries of the South. This means that cohesion policy must be strengthened and not weakened, because in recent years we have seen a weakening. The criteria must also be changed so that money from cohesion policy and more can be made and gone where there is greater poverty, greater unemployment, greater social inequalities, greater disinvestment. And of course it is necessary for my country, Greece, which in recent days has suffered a major natural disaster with dead, floods, disasters, to move the Solidarity Fund urgently and quickly on the basis of the regulations provided for.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express the strong support of us in the League for this report, for this EUSALP strategy strongly desired by the northern regions of my country, and in particular by Lombardy.  It is a belated answer, of course, but finally a serious and promising answer to the many questions that come from these extraordinary Alpine peoples, linked to their territory, to their identity, perhaps a little less to the great works, but strongly anxious to see the hand of Europe, the solidarity of Europe, which until now has been seen very little, compared to their communication needs , productivity, support for the start-up of different activities.  And then, however, there is a big question – because one has to ask, the Commissioner must ask himself, the rapporteur must ask, the rapporteur should ask for it – namely the political support of the Member States, for example in our country, where there is a Renzi government proposing a reform of the Constitution that nullifies the powers of the regions! And then they go to Ventotene – they should be ashamed! – and then they talk about the Chivasso Charter: they should be ashamed! So strong defence of local rights and authorities, regions and municipalities... (The speaker was interrupted.)

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Congratulations to the rapporteurs, Honourable Commissioner. Cohesion policy is intended for the first time for countries and regions with development backlogs to eliminate these development backlogs, secondly, to steer the development of new technologies, to make a development breakthrough in countries, and, thirdly, to bring countries together and people all over Europe. The reports also relate to these areas. Let me touch two. First of all, we report around smart specialisation: we have a very large deficit in Europe, so that we do not know how to establish effective cooperation between the economy and science, research, innovation. This is why Europe is now in a development behind. I fear that the introduction of smart specialisation in some countries is also lagging behind, because the actors do not understand this importance. I therefore ask for action so that this area of cohesion will be well realised even during this programming period. The next area that is concerned today is the alpine region, the strategy for the Alpine region. I come from Slovenia, which also presides over the Alpine region. We were together at the first meeting of this Alpine region, Honourable Commissioner, and it is indeed an opportunity for the countries that live in this beautiful space, on the one hand, to live in this space and, on the other hand, to economic activity, and to maintain life and economic activity in the area by sharing their experience.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – In my speech, I would like to address small and medium-sized enterprises, because it is precisely on the report on increasing the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises that I tabled amendments in our REGI committee and they are also part of the motion for a resolution.  We do not need to talk much about how important small and medium-sized enterprises are in terms of the European Union's economy and in terms of creating new jobs and employing people, including in remote regions and small settlements, and we all agree on that. It is therefore essential to create conditions for small and medium-sized enterprises at Member State level as large enterprises. They must have equal access to State aid, the interest rates on their financing must be equal. Equating them with large enterprises would be a crucial element for modernising, developing services, knowledge and creating new jobs. I also consider it important to comply more thoroughly with the directives currently in force, which require, among other things, that public administrations make payments within thirty days, which is precisely not respected for small and medium-sized enterprises.  Small and medium-sized enterprises do not have a large administration or can afford it, so simplifying the administrative burden, even when drawing on the Structural Funds, must be a priority for any legislation at European Union level, but also for the Member States. Finally, I would really like to thank all the rapporteurs for their perfect report.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is to be welcomed that the Alpine regions are to be strengthened economically, that rail-bound transport networks are recognised as a factor, and that the protection of the water resources there is also essential. For the sensitive Alpine region, the focus must also be on nature conservation. Whether the settlement of predators, i.e. birds of prey and predators, alone, as envisaged in the report, secures biodiversity, is a matter of debate from a hunting point of view.  It is therefore very important in these strategies that the alpine cultural landscape is dealt with and that the wildlife is also cared for, and of course those who carry out these measures must also be taken into account. I am thinking in particular of our farmers and foresters, who ultimately ensure the preservation of our alpine cultural area. They need fair prices for their excellent products and no handouts. We should also think of them in this strategy.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Alpine region as a whole is a complex system, interspersed with borders, political borders, and also interspersed with difficult transport routes. The Alpine region is an important tourist area, if you only think of the fact that around one hundred million people holiday in the Alpine region every year, making this Alpine region the most important holiday destination in Europe. In the Alpine region there are very developed regions and, besides, often very underdeveloped regions, and therefore a common strategy is very right. A common transport strategy and the transfer of transport to rail is also the right thing to do, and this requires major investment, both at the Brenner, where I come from, on the Fréjus line and on the Turin-Lyon line, and that is why I am absolutely opposed to the amendments that have been tabled here.  The Alpine region is a natural area; it is a cultural area; above all, however, it is also an economic area. As the previous speaker has already said, it seems that in the Alpine region, the big predators are obviously to be re-established by force.
