I think that if we do that, and if we do not give the people who live there the opportunity to intervene, then this sensitive balance is clearly shifting in favour of the natural area, and the cultural and economic area will suffer as a result. From this point of view too, we should really consider whether the Alpine region really needs wolves and bears everywhere in all regions.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, first of all I would like to take this opportunity to thank you for the sensitivity and readiness you showed with your statements in the post-earthquake period in central Italy, regarding the Commission's willingness to reprogramme interventions on the basis of the needs of that territory, which has been severely and dramatically affected in terms of lives and structures.  Cohesion policy must create growth, development but above all employment. A stable and lasting well-being cannot ignore a solid industrial fabric that can grow and expand. Small and medium-sized enterprises are at the base of this fabric, especially in less developed economic contexts such as southern Italy. Small and medium-sized enterprises are the real driving force behind the economy, and it is therefore up to them to turn to cohesion policy.  Unfortunately, however, reality tells us that the Structural Funds are not yet tailored to small and medium-sized enterprises because there are major obstacles to overcome. Two of them: bureaucracy and access to credit. As the report rightly emphasises, small and medium-sized enterprises still face too many barriers because of the complexity of the programming system at all stages. And then there is access to credit: support for cohesion policy is essential for the new financial instruments that allow banks to release supervisory capital, and it is even more important that local administrators are able to take advantage of these instruments through which small and medium-sized enterprises can create development.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, first of all a comment on SMEs, which represent the backbone of our economy. We must therefore facilitate their ability to operate and trade across Europe, especially in the creative and media sector. Any strategy on SMEs must include support for cooperatives, social enterprises and alternative business models because these have so much potential for a more ethical way of doing business and can bring about accountability to the private sector. We must also ensure that vulnerable excluded groups have access to entrepreneurship education, particularly women and girls who face greater obstacles and prejudice. With reference to innovation and the need to build synergies between cohesion policy and innovation strategies, innovation is by definition a cross-cutting concept. So I welcome the efforts to better coordinate funding tools that are crucial for the sustainable development of European regions in both urban and rural areas. Last July I attended the European Science Open Forum in Manchester in my Northwest constituency where I co—hosted a session on the links between the arts and science together with my colleague Eva Kaili. This session confirmed the demand in both communities to change the silo mentality. Businesses, scientists and artists all argued in favour of a more global approach to innovation and to jointly explore their common impact on societies. This should be the essence of smart specialisation strategies. They should not only be seen as a tick-box exercise. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Rampant corruption is the biggest cancer of any EU cohesion programme or financial assistance programme. This kind of news comes from a whole range of EU Member States. Unfortunately, the worst examples come from my country, Hungary. Where there has been almost no day in the last few years when the press has not discovered a corruption case linked to a politician in the government or to financiers or oligarchs associated with it. The real problem, however, is that these corruption cases are not followed by criminal proceedings and end in punishment. Indeed, there are Member States, Hungary, where the public prosecutor's office is reluctant to act on corruption cases involving pro-government politicians. It is no coincidence that it is always the Member States who are most afraid that their own politicians and their own environment may be involved in these matters that are most likely to refuse to set up a Common European Public Prosecutor's Office. That's an admission. If a member state government does not want to set up a joint EU public prosecutor's office to investigate these types of corruption, it is actually saying that it does not want these corruption cases to be investigated or investigated. We therefore propose that, if not now, only Those Member States that undertake to set up a joint EU Public Prosecutor's Office should receive EU funding in the cohesion period after 2020. It's not possible to take the money, but it's not possible to commit crimes... (The President has withdrawn the floor from the Member.)

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, being born in the Balkans is not always a bad thing. The harsh reality there gives you the opportunity to see the most rational solution, however difficult and complex a question or problem may seem to you. From this point of view, I would like to tell you that I am truly sorry to hear that there are voices in this Chamber calling for the restriction of cohesion policy.  Dear colleagues, cohesion policy is not a cake we can cut from every time it comes to our mind. Behind it is the European budget, the Multiannual Financial Framework, national budgets designed to finance hundreds of projects. Hundreds of regions rely on us. Do we want to shoot ourselves in the leg? Those same voices I want to ask: What will remain if we restrict this policy? Talk, colleagues, just talk. And people have heard enough of them. I'm sure this chamber has heard many and all sorts of things, but this time the voice that will prevail is the voice of reason. There are certainly issues that we need to raise, but they are not about cohesion policy. They are about excessive bureaucracy or why 70% of Horizon goes to six countries. I'm sure this time the voice of reason will prevail.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I very much appreciate today's debate, because I believe that nothing can be more important for a united Europe than cohesion.  I want to refer specifically to the SME report, because I am also vice-chair of the SME intergroup. It is important to have new measures, but I think it is even more important to check, Commissioner, sure, through the national authorities, what the effect of applying these measures is. Because SMEs still do not have access, not only to finance, not to public procurement, to the labour market, nor to research and innovation. And then I think it is very important, if we are talking about cohesion and this is in the Treaty, let us also talk about the Strategic Investment Fund which does not help cohesion.  The Strategic Investment Fund, without regional, geographical criteria, increases regional disparities, does not lead to cohesion; therefore, I ask you, Commissioner, to try to discuss halfway through your mandate, now, if you cannot review those criteria set - first come, first served - at the Strategic Fund.  And I also think that we need, in particular, to think about start-ups and the creation of new jobs, and this, as you said, can be done through discussion with national authorities, cross-border, through all the other reports that have been exposed here, whether we are talking about research-innovation, the Alpine project and so on.  That is why I hope that improving our cohesion is a matter of the treaty and compliance with these rules.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, innovation is one of the most clearly demonstrating areas that an efficient European Union needs to completely change its governance paradigms. The regions, the areas of development and intelligent specialization that promote innovation by leveraging their strengths and the natural synergies that arise from them, demonstrate that the sometimes more protectionist state logic that it promotes, is not the one that best suits the promotion and support of the productive economy. I am pleased that the Commission is increasingly taking on this logic, which has allowed, for example the Basque Country, to integrate into the head group of European regions with smart specialization strategies, to maintain the weight of industry in its gross domestic product and not to lose the train of competitiveness in a global area. Maintaining that capacity for strategic action and improving that position, which is the basis of quality job creation and is the first sense of our policies and demands as a country.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, I am talking about a period where unacceptable blackmail by the European Commission against Portugal and its people continues. Recognizing the failure of all the austerity plans that have solved neither the problems of the economy nor the problems of public finances, the Portuguese decided in October 2015 democratically to interrupt the hellish cycle of the troika policies that sank the country. Since then, Portugal has since ceased to be the exemplary student of Brussels to being the target of all blackmail, which now includes cutting the structural funds.  This reveals the true nature of this European Union, which is not at all concerned with cohesion and the correction of national and regional asymmetries. Instead of recognising the failure of its policies, not only in Portugal but in most Member States, the European Commission now wants to further punish the countries buffeted by austerity, further aggravating the European garrote and compromising all possibilities for the recovery of our economy. Unfortunate.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, small and medium-sized enterprises are the most important driver of growth and job creation in the EU. 23 million SMEs employ more than 100 million people and create 85% of new jobs. In France, some 3.5 million SMEs and TPEs employ more than 6 out of 10 people. I have been a small business manager for 40 years and have found that often policy proposals are too far removed from the reality experienced by entrepreneurs. Of course, this report makes good observations and good recommendations, but let us forget the partisan and ideological quarrels to be effective. Let us demonstrate the spirit of innovation and pragmatism that we ask business leaders to avoid the policy being further behind the economy. Governments have a very basic view of the economy: add taxes, impose laws, give subsidies. SMEs need a stable tax environment, fewer administrative constraints, more access to credit, but also smart protections against dumping. That is the reality of the needs.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, improving the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises is not just a matter of financing. No matter how much money is invested, it will not bring growth on its own. If it were that simple, the billions of euros allocated by the European Structural and Investment Funds would have to be translated into reduced indicators of unemployment and internal migration. The Union must adopt measures and rules that promote the establishment and development of small and medium-sized enterprises and support their survival in the competitive environment with large enterprises. I will refer to three simple measures: the abolition of bureaucratic barriers to the creation of small and medium-sized enterprises by establishing a pan-European model, a directive applicable by all Member States to create a favourable environment in two directions: the transition to a low-carbon circular economy and the promotion of green products and services, the combination of the Structural Funds with other resources that will promote bank lending for small and medium-sized enterprises; , finally, the development of a single tax practice for small and medium-sized enterprises that will allow taxation after a certain grace period or impose uniform tax scales from all Member States.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission.– Thank you very much, thank you, first of all, for this very interesting discussion and for your contribution, for the very useful ideas put forward by the representatives of the European Parliament's specialised committees.  As regards what has been said here in relation to SMEs, it has been as a milkmotiv for all the discussions, I agree that support from cohesion policy is essential to boost the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, which is, as has been said here, on numerous occasions, the backbone of the European economy.  As a general remark, I would like to say that I am very pleased that most speakers have stressed the importance of cohesion policy, despite what really needs to be improved. I believe that cohesion policy is the most visible policy by which people's daily lives practically improve, have a considerable impact in all regions of the European Union, in all Member States, whether developed or less developed.  As far as small and medium-sized enterprises are concerned, EUR 90 billion is available by 2020 and we are doing everything in our power to make the most of these opportunities. In particular, I believe that we have made significant efforts together to reduce red tape in support of programme beneficiaries, and I believe that we should have a closer dialogue with the CONT Commission, because you know very well that there is a point of view in the Committee on Regional Policy and a completely different point of view in the Committee on Budgetary Control , where, indeed, the question of control of taxpayers' money, how this money is invested is raised. With regard to Mr Valcárcel's report, of course we want a successful cohesion policy. We need very good smart specialisation strategies. To this end, I believe that, as you said, we must ensure that all stakeholders, in particular local and regional authorities, universities, academia, research institutions, socio-economic partners, small and medium-sized enterprises, have the means to exploit the potential of smart specialisation strategies.  As mentioned, we have set up a smart specialised strategy platform, we have also created a series of thematic platforms that already provide specific support in areas such as energy, food industry, agri-food, digital or the circular economy depending on the specialisation chosen by each region. You know very well, my position is that every region is unique, not every region can be Silicon Valley, so every region has to find its strengths to lean on. And of course we will continue to provide assistance, and I hope that this assistance will be useful in making the best use of the various funds available. With regard to Mrs Iskra Mihaylova's own-initiative report on European territorial cooperation, I welcome once again the European Parliament's strong support for territorial cooperation. I believe that INTERREG has proven to be a laboratory of European integration.  Border regions are, in fact, the places where we can best show what Europe means and can do. 25% of Europe's population lives around borders. I believe that we need to give new impetus to this cross-border cooperation. As I was saying, we are working to lift administrative barriers.  I welcome, for example, the very good cooperation that exists between Germany and Poland, but, for example, between Belgium and France, although language is not an obstacle, we cannot have the same cooperation because the legislation is not aligned. So I think it is very important to lift all these barriers, especially at this time, when the temporary reintroduction of border controls increases the difficulties faced by these regions.  I believe that political action aimed at promoting prosperity in these regions is more than necessary. With regard to the INTERREG timetable, we are in the process of implementing INTERREG 5 in the period 2014-2020 and we are already seeing the beneficial effects of simplification and we are working on this cross-border cross-border review, which will be a useful basis for the development of the next programme cycle, INTERREG 6. With regard to mrs Mercedes Bresso's report, the Alpine region, the Alpine strategy, as pointed out here, as Mrs Bresso also pointed out, I believe that the Alpine strategy should be an essential component of future territorial cooperation.  In December, the Commission will present the half-yearly report on the processes recorded in the conduct of all macro-regional strategies, as requested in the report, and, sure ly, this report will provide a first assessment of the Union strategy European Union for the Alpine region, as well as an overview of how territorial cooperation should look in the future in order to better serve European citizens and, in particular, those living in border areas, in less developed areas. As conclusions, these are the main issues i would like to discuss at this stage. Unfortunately, the rules governing the time allocated to interventions do not allow me to respond to the many problems that you have raised in the four reports, but I would like, if I may, to say two things. I find it absolutely unfair, and Mr Fontous from Greece has left, as a country that has benefited from billions of euros in recent years, since 1981, when he became a member of the European Union, to talk about the fact that cohesion policy exists only in the aisles of the European Union. I would like to invite all Greek parliamentarians, maybe go together to see to what extent Greece has benefited, and I would like to thank you, Members of the European Parliament, for taking exceptional measures for an exceptional situation, and I do not think it is right that a country that now benefits from 100% co-financing, as no other country benefits , I do not think it is right to come and attack this cohesion policy!  Let us look: would the Athens metro have been without 90% co-financing from the European Union? We are now waiting to build the Thessaloniki metro! Would there have been thousands of schools and hospitals across Greece? Would there have been thousands of miles of highway? What did Greece look like before 1981, when it entered the European Union? So, as Mr Papadimoulis said, I believe that cohesion policy has contributed massively to improving the situation in which Greece has been on numerous occasions and, as a man who has fought both with the European Commission and here in the European Parliament, together with you, in the Committee on Regional Development to facilitate and help Greece, I find it absolutely unfair and even an insult to your work and the Commission in finding solutions to save and improve people's lives in Greece. So, from this point of view, I wanted to make this statement, because it is absolutely unfair. With regard to what happened in Madeira, in Italy, this summer, Of course, I personally express my solidarity. We have already spoken, the Italian authorities have until mid-November to apply for the solidarity fund.  Unfortunately, Italy is the country that has benefited the most, more than EUR 1.3 billion for this prevention of calamities. A significant amount of money went to Italy in 2009 on the occasion of the Aquila cutrem. Another significant amount of money for earthquake prevention went to Italy in 2012 on the occasion of the cutrem in the Emilia Romagna region. Let's see what happened to all these disaster prevention plans. And we are ready, and this time, to contribute, we are ready to change the operational-regional programme, if it requires it, but I think we need to see to what extent the amounts that have been allocated during these disasters in recent years in Italy, because indeed, as you say, the apennine area, which is the backbone of Italy, is subject to these massive attempts, to invest this money as best we can.  And in Madeira I will be pleased to come to the annual meeting of the outermost regions on 22 September this month, and, of course, how we can help Madeira together with the solidarity fund will be one of the topics that we will address together with the authorities in this region. You know very well that for me the outermost regions are a special subject and we will once again have the opportunity to meet again, members of the European Parliament from these regions who, in my opinion, require special treatment.  Thank you very much. (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner. You mentioned Mr Fountoulis. Unfortunately, it is no longer there. Sometimes it would be good if colleagues who speak and then leave are not rewarded by addressing them again.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at the end of this debate, I wanted to highlight a few aspects that are fundamental to me: the economic crisis, yes, but above all austerity policies have stifled domestic demand and so have businesses and our small and medium-sized enterprises. These must be helped in access to credit. To this end, we must ensure that the relationship between the banking system and small businesses is improved and changed. The financial instruments currently have very high risk profiles, and we do not yet have any evidence to suggest that they should be used favoured more favourfully than subsidies.  The Capital Market Union is also a very important initiative and we do not share the optimism regardless of the Commission. What we need to invest in is administrative capacity, transparency, greater transparency in the use of funds, the higher rate of participation of all local authorities, civil society actors and entrepreneurs in the process of defining the requirements for submitting project proposals in order to respond more specifically to the needs of the final beneficiaries. We must apply the partnership principle rigidly and prevent cohesion policy from being perceived as further imposition from above. Cohesion policy can be highly improved, but as the European Union's main investment instrument it must be vigorously defended. In this respect, the Member States, and especially those of southern Europe, which have so far been the main users, bear a huge responsibility. Among these states, many have not yet expressed a clear position in the face of this threat.  In fact, faced with the pressure of other leaner European funding programmes, such as Horizon 2020, cohesion policy and its programmes are perceived as retrograde, but we therefore do not understand that the rationale of these real policies is completely different. Cohesion policy remains perhaps the only truly democratic and deeply unified instrument of our community.

text: PPE), in writing. – It is our firm position that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the backbone of the European economy. They also account for more than 90% of all European enterprises and employ two thirds of the number of workers in Europe. It is indisputable that the development of SMEs is a crucial condition for boosting Europe's competitiveness and attracting investment and production units. What we expect from European legislation is to support small and medium-sized enterprises to effectively expand their activities on international markets. For the period 2007-2013, supported by cohesion policy, EUR 70 billion has been allocated to support companies, mainly SMEs, and we welcome the target of doubling this amount for the period 2014-2020.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The European Structural and Investment Funds are the main promoters of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the Union. Cohesion policy is an investment policy with tangible results and has been through very exemplary reforms in recent times. The accruals-based reform that has taken place could also be an example for other areas of expenditure in the EU budget. Cohesion policy faces a number of new challenges that need to be solved by respecting the policy's original and still relevant objectives and the specific needs of the regions. There is a general shift from infrastructure developments to developments supporting the knowledge-based economy, but it should be bearing in mind that infrastructure development cannot continue to be overshadowed because infrastructure is often deficient in more developed Member States, development cannot always be solved on a market basis, and proper infrastructure interconnection is also a prerequisite for the functioning of the single internal market. Over the period 2014-2020, the proportion of financial instruments has increased significantly at the expense of grants, and this trend is expected to continue to strengthen. I think it is important to stress that, although financial instruments can be useful, they cannot always provide a feasible solution, since many developments have significant social value but do not result in direct financial gain. name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Ignazio Corrao on behalf of the Development Committee on the EU Trust Fund for Africa: Impact on Development and Humanitarian Aid (2015/2341(INI)) (A8-0221/2016).

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the title of the report we are debating today may suggest distant problems, but in reality it deals with issues that are very close to the citizens of Europe and of absolute topicality. The Africa Trust Fund is an extremely sensitive instrument that must be well planned, made to function effectively and finally communicated properly.  Today, Europe is at a crossroads: it has the opportunity to make a positive impact on the lives of millions of people, or it can be guided by national fear and selfishness and thus fail in its objectives. The Trust Fund for Africa is designed to respond to the need to eradicate the root causes of migration through interventions aimed at creating development in those countries that are the scene of mass migration.  In order to make the Fund effective, it is necessary: 1) to operate in the long term in a defined and programmatic way, thus avoiding intervening only in an emergency key; 2) pay particular attention to the least developed countries, making the appropriate differences between the different contexts; 3) invest in education, health, training and essential public services; 4) involve NGOs and local civil society in the planning and implementation of all projects on the ground; (5) provide for regular monitoring and monitoring by this Parliament of the use of funds; (6) to make provision for transparency, information and dissemination of results which are easily verifiable by citizens; (7) to require States to keep their promises on additional funding.  For these reasons, the report I am presenting in this House seeks to make it clear that we agree both on putting together more resources in order to intervene at the base of the problem and on the nature of an instrument that allows rapid action to be taken in the face of urgent situations, just as we agree to restore the necessary budget units.  At the same time, however, we cannot fail to point out that there are still some concerns. The acceding states, for example, are making a great effort – as we saw at the Valletta summit last November – but then, in the spotlight off, they forget their promises and commitments. In addition, we must point out the real risk that development funds could be diverted to other areas, such as border control of the countries involved. This type of intervention has nothing to do with development and will never solve the root of the problem.  I will conclude by emphasising that all these issues have been the focus of a constructive debate between the political parties, which has continued even at the stage of the amendments and after the vote in the Committee on Development. Similarly, thanks to the instruments of online democratic participation that we use as the 5-Star Movement, such as the Rousseau system, many citizens have had the opportunity to get to know the draft report and to express their opinion, and some of these observations have been transformed into amendments signed by me and have been included in the text voted on in committee. Finally, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their willingness in recent months to contribute to the drafting of a good parliamentary report on such a sensitive issue.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Mr President, from our point of view, it is clearly logical that the Commission proposes the creation of this fund, because this should allow us to disburse funds more quickly and flexibly, to have extrabudgetary funding and also to improve the coordination of policies and instruments in that region. But this is by no means a blank cheque for any kind of policy to be financed, and I would like to make it clear that we will not allow it to divert money from the objectives and priorities that had already been agreed on or, of course, to jeopardize the development cooperation policy. I would also like to recall that one of the reasons for the set up of this fund was to facilitate the contributions of the Member States, the budgetary contributions and, of course, this has not happened today and these contributions remain shamefully derisory. Finally, I would like to point out that the need to create such instruments is because of the zero capacity of the budgets to adapt to new circumstances, although I believe that this will be smartly resolved by the Commission in the proposal which it will make to us in two days.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am here on behalf of my dear colleague Neven Mimica, and I would like to welcome this report and congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Corrao. The EU Trust Fund for Africa was created as a swift and flexible implementing tool to, inter alia, better manage migration and deliver quick results. The Trust Fund reduces the risk of aid fragmentation and provides a platform for political visibility and engagement with countries of origin, transit and destination.  In the three regions concerned – the Sahel and Lake Chad, the Horn of Africa and the North of Africa – the root causes of instability, forced displacement and irregular migration are diverse, complex and often inter-related. They thus require a holistic and integrated approach.  I have personally witnessed this in my visits to Mali, Somalia, Ethiopia, Kenya and lately in the last few months to Niger and Chad. I saw the situation on the ground and I strongly believe that the EU Trust Fund is definitely supporting programmes aimed at creating employment opportunities in local communities of origin and return, with a focus on vocational training and the creation of micro and small enterprises. It also supports actions aimed at strengthening access to basic services across a variety of resilience programmes. It particularly targets young people and women as well as other vulnerable groups.  The EU Trust Fund for Africa complements existing EU instruments, national and regional frameworks as well as bilateral programmes of EU Member States. Development cooperation addresses migration issues in two ways: firstly, by helping partner countries to improve migration governance, tapping into the development potential of migration; and secondly, by addressing political, economic and social instability, development cooperation addresses the causes of irregular migration and forced displacement, in order to help ensure that migration takes place in an orderly and safe manner. The Trust Fund supports programmes aiming at better migration management, including affording international protection, offering long-term solutions to displaced people and facilitating the safe, and also dignified and sustainable, return of migrants. This is in line with the United Nations’ 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and these are clearly development objectives. In the design and implementation of activities, the Commission follows three key principles. Firstly, the need for a strong human rights focus, especially in actions in support of law enforcement and border management; secondly, the need for continuous monitoring to ensure that European Union support is used for its intended purpose and is delivering the expected results; and thirdly, the need to be transparent and inclusive with EU Member States, African partners, and relevant international organisations and civil society.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. As shadow rapporteur for the EPP Group, I would like to thank Mr Corrao for his cooperation in this motion for a resolution. The Trust Fund for Africa is a new instrument aimed at addressing the root causes of destabilisation of forced displacement and irregular immigration. However, it must not replace effective border management and control and must be subject to transparency rules not only in terms of its implementation, but also in terms of funding.  The regions of the Horn of Africa, the Sahel and the Lake Chad basin and the North Africa covered are among the most fragile in the context of the current migration and refugee crisis, and therefore the Fund will only deliver results if faster and more flexible spending is linked to long-term development objectives, namely the provision of peace and the rule of law and the implementation of good governance practices by beneficiary countries.  The political will of partner countries is crucial, as the Fund is also intended to strengthen their local capacity for ownership and responsibility. It is difficult to expect that such ad hoc support will have immediate effects, and therefore the Fund should be seen as a complementary action 11. European Development Fund. A coherent development policy and the principle of complementarity between all instruments and actors in development aid must also be respected in this case. We must place great emphasis on the need to increase member states' involvement and meet not only the commitments on contributions to the Trust Fund, but also more broadly to ODA, especially in the context of reducing Member States' contributions to this year's Union budget thanks to the EUR 1.3 billion surplus of 2015.

text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Good evening, Commissioner. As shadow rapporteur for the S&D Group, I would like to draw particular attention to two aspects of this fund. It concerns the Sahel, the region around Lake Chad, the Horn of Africa and North Africa. If someone wants to flee and is entitled to an asylum procedure in Europe, they must not be prevented from doing so. Increased border controls mean that smugglers come up with even more daring strategies and put people fleeing hardship at risk.  That is why we must pay close attention to what the money is spent on in the regions. And in planning projects and in monitoring, the EU Parliament – that is, us – as a democratically elected institution should have greater influence.  The second point concerns the financing of projects through the trust funds. It must not lead to long-term projects enabling real development being jeopardised in favour of short-term programmes.  Most of the trust fund is financed by the European Development Fund, which is outside the EU budget. However, the use of financial instruments outside the EU budget is unsustainable. The reason for this is that the Member States can voluntarily contribute their contributions and set the sums themselves. text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, since mass migration to Europe began, as a member of the Committee on Development and Vice-President of the Subcommittee on Human Rights, I have argued that it is essential to address the root causes that lead millions of people to forced displacement. The establishment of this emergency fund, Commissioner Stylianides, aims to contribute to the solution of this problem, but the form is not adequate. We need a real strategy to end instability and poverty; a strategy in perfect coordination with all areas involved in the external affairs of the European Union; a strategy with new funds, which do not undermine the current plans of the European Development Fund. But this has been the Commission's proposal and we have to work on it. Therefore, I would like to make some considerations to you. Thanks to the great work of my colleague, Mr Corrao, many of these complaints are in this report. Listen to us, because we are the voice of 500 million citizens.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the European Commission's proposal for a EUR 1.8 billion Fund for Africa might seem, to the naked eye, a good idea for countries such as Uganda, Mali or Senegal. Now, when we see what these 1.8 billion are specifically for, the idea becomes perverse and repulsive. The aim is to allocate resources from official development aid to the control of migrants. The money for Eritrea, Somalia or Ethiopia will no longer be to build schools or to improve their public health policies. The money is now for them to act as policemen on Europe's borders. This is a new episode of outsourcing border control, using impoverished countries, wary countries or countries with criminal dictatorships. The aim of this fund is to buy from these countries to prevent migrants from leaving their country, prevent them from passing or accept them into their country after being deported from Europe. A blackmail fund. Money in exchange for them repressing and controlling migration flows. We are talking about funds for governments, in many cases corrupt, which permanently violate human rights, such as the Government of Sudan, whose President is persecuted by the International Criminal Court. When we say that we have to act at the origin, we certainly do not mean this. We are talking about acting on the real causes of the impoverishment of countries. And I end up simply thanking Mr. Corrao for his work. We don't have the problem with your report, but with the trust fund itself.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, it is, of course, in your best interest that we are going to address the so-called root causes of migration and the need of millions of people who have been forcibly displaced. But I am afraid that when I listen to you defending the Trust Fund I cannot take you 100% seriously. Why? Because we are concerned that the Trust Fund constitutes yet another attempt to divert the diminishing development funds towards aims related to protecting Europe from people fleeing war and poverty – and this is not acceptable. We cannot be sure that the internationally agreed principles of development effectiveness are fulfilled. Parliament has extremely limited rights of scrutiny and, as already mentioned by colleagues, if we look at how this fund was put together, we can conclude that, despite the expectation that Member States would be eager to contribute to it, the contributions by Member States to complement EU development funding, mainly from the European Development Fund (EDF), have been extremely limited – to my knowledge around EUR 69 million. So why, again, a separate structure which diverts our work from really addressing the root causes? Of course, we have colleagues like Mr Halla-aho who says that migration control should be the main aim of spending on EU development assistance, but I could not disagree with him more. We have to come back to making sure that we really help people’s everyday lives: that we create livelihoods, we build schools, we help with health and education and we support women and girls. A lot of other things can be done but, please, not with development money. We have another example which is very topical: we have this amendment to the Regulation on the Instrument contributing to Peace and Stability, and I am sorry to say it but this is yet another attempt to divert development money to other purposes.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
