name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, foreign aid should be about helping a country that is not as well off as our own by providing them with medicines, schools and equipment to have clean water and to grow their own food. This way, developing nations do not continually have to rely on aid from developed countries as they will have the tools to grow their own country without the unwanted influence of the European Union and its vanity projects. Overseas aid can be good if used properly in the short term, but it does not help developing nations out of poverty in the long term. The only way that this can be achieved is by removing barriers to trade, rather than giving aid handouts. If handouts are continually given, this will lead to corrupt leaders purposefully obstructing economic growth within their country which, in turn, will lead to a total misuse of British taxpayers’ funds. We should not be using development aid funds to further the EU’s expansionist policies by influencing political participation and governance. This is not acceptable and it is one of the reasons why the United Kingdom voted to leave the EU.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has In 2009, the Lisbon Treaty gave the European Parliament full codecision on the European Union's budgetary issues, on the European budget. And now we are seeing everywhere that parts of the budget are being taken out of the multiannual financial framework or even from the annual budget parts in order to set up such trust funds, as here too the 'Trust Fund for Africa: impact on development and humanitarian aid', in order to once again keep Parliament out and deprive it of its rights. Of the 1.8 billion allocated to this fund, 375 million come from the Development Cooperation and Humanitarian Aid Instrument and the Neighbourhood Instrument. For all three instruments, we had sufficient reasons to keep the funds there. Now we are coming up with a new strategy, which has once again been devised outside Parliament. When the Council in La Valletta sat with the representatives of the African regimes, it was precisely and often the people who, with their policies in their countries, ultimately contribute to the flight of many people. In other words, how do we now want to solve the problems that often have political causes by trying to turn the buck into a gardener? 1.8 billion is not much, and the objectives pursued by the Fund are a mish-mash of support for good governance or improved governance, and on the other hand of development projects, as we already have in the other development measures. For example, when I read that 80 million from the ninth EDF, the European Development Fund – now we have the eleventh – should be made available for South Sudan, I wonder how this will be implemented if not a single aid transport arrives in that country at the moment, because the civil war is still raging. So, here are more questions than answers are given. We need to step up our debate on the usefulness of such trust funds.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteurs and my fellow Members for their work. There are many doubts and critical issues in Parliament, which I would say are legitimate, with regard to the Trust Fund instrument. The first concerns member states' contributions: we are at 81.8 million, a little compared with what the Commission has already made available – EUR 1.8 billion. Secondly, these resources must be used to tackle poverty, inequalities and the root causes of migration, and certainly not border management, the outsourcing of our borders. I would like to understand what the Commission means when it says that one of the objectives is to help these countries manage flows better. Providing young people with education to realise their potential and create job opportunities: this serves to promote sustainable development. Raising walls, on the other hand, only increases inequalities.  The ultimate aim of the EU's development policy, as enshrined in Article 208 of the Treaty, must be the reduction and eradication of poverty. Respect for human rights must also be ensured as a condition, not as an optional one, in order to prevent these funds from going into the hands of liberticidal regimes. Finally, I would not like the proliferation of these emergency instruments to result in the abandonment of the Community method and also of budgetary unity. This Parliament must have full and democratic scrutiny, and the same applies to the involvement of civil society in the implementation of this instrument.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: - Madam President, I congratulate Mr Corrao on his report, because he draws attention to fundamental problems in these funds, stressing the following: in the model EU Trust Fund for Africa, once again, the European Union's geostrategic interests prevail over the interest in contributing to the development of migrant countries of transit and origin; democratic control over these funds is very in deficit and, unfortunately, this House has very little power in its design and implementation; we hardly paint anything. Once again we are looking at an example of the inconsistency of the European Union's policies. Under the pretext of influencing the root causes of human mobility, this Fund allocates official development aid resources to the outsourcing of border control and control of people, rather than to the promotion of development in countries of origin. To raise fences to poverty and despair is not to contribute to development under any circumstances. I once again call for the need for a migration and trade foreign policy consistent with our objectives, human rights and the SDGs, which the European Union so pompously signed within the United Nations.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: – Madam President, Europe has always been a leading donor for people in need, but today there is more at stake than before in terms of aid. Mass migration creates a new humanitarian and security situation, not only in Africa but in Europe. Our primary task is to lend a hand in crisis areas. The EU Trust Fund aims to prevent displacement but we have to go further and we need a clear strategy. I would like a really clear strategy on protecting vulnerable communities in their homeland. Without a common European strategy we cannot overcome the challenges of irregular migration. If you look at Africa, displacement is often driven by religious hatred. Europe is responsible for these people, whose basic rights are in danger. We need to join forces in relief activities, and the EU Trust Fund that we have discussed today strongly promotes this idea. Let me make a serious suggestion here: EU action will be more effective if we bring religious organisations on board as well. They manage efficiently functioning local relief networks. The efficiency of organised church bodies often exceeds that of public aid. It would be a failure to ignore their local experience as they have a significant impact on creating social stability. Without this cooperation, negative impacts will increase in the future. We need a new level of comprehensive support in this situation: we are helping them and they are showing up in Europe. The recent illegal migration has been handled through the improvement of security and economic development to stop the displacement. Finally, I thank my colleagues very much for their efforts in this work.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, as the budget rapporteur for the Committee on Foreign Affairs I want to raise a number of concerns on the use of Trust Funds as an instrument. I appreciate why the funds were created; it was basically to enable the EU to respond to many new crises that were unforeseen by the Multiannual Framework and to bring on board new donors. However, we have a situation where the African Trust Fund is currently short of EUR 1.7 billion due to lack of Member States’ contributions.  Now how is this gap to be plugged? I hope not by taking away resources from our long-standing commitments to sustainable development goals and undermining other goals that the EP has set which are already in need of additional resources. So what we need urgently is a fully resourced and a permanent EU crisis reserve. It is incredulous that some members of the Trust Fund have a seat on the board and have a say on how it is executed with contributions of as little as EUR 50 000, when the European Parliament, despite its 1.8 billion contribution, is not represented.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Madam President, it is essential to promote the stability of these regions and to contribute to better migration management. However, as has already been reiterated here, only 4.5 % of the commitments made by the Member States have been implemented. Already in 2005, the European Union and its Member States also committed to increasing official development aid to 0.7 % of the Gross National Income of the European Union by 2015.  As a whole, we continue to miss this goal: this commitment has now moved to 2030. The European Union must tackle the migration crisis and invest in improving the living conditions of people in the most deprived countries, and not to bet, through fear of hunger and barbed wire, on keeping migrants on Europe's borders. On the other hand, we must be aware of possible misuse of this money, strengthening the supervisory role of the European Parliament. European taxpayers would not understand if this fund were strengthening dictators and despots, but this should not be confused with aid and solidarity with third countries.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would also like to express my support in my contribution to my colleagues, who have raised questions precisely about the functioning of this fund and its implementation. I think that the link to the current issues of the parties to migration has been highlighted quite sufficiently in the debate, so I would address another subject that relates to a point that we regularly have on Parliament's agenda here, and that is a human rights issue. I believe that we should also pay attention if EU funds are directed to support various African countries, as even the basic human rights are respected there, because this is a subject that has been discussed many times here. I think it is quite shameful if we criticise specific countries for specific human rights violations and if european citizens' resources go to such countries in the long term. I think we should really think about it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, 1.5 billion people worldwide live in so-called vulnerable areas affected by conflict, lawlessness and growing corruption. The largest population living in such areas is the population of Africa. It is therefore important to provide financial support to the countries of Africa, because this is the only way to avoid the mass exodus of its populations caused by impoverishment and lack of prospects. Sincere support is therefore needed for the economies most struggling to cope with economic globalisation. At the same time, however, all sustainable development models must be supported first and cooperation between the countries and peoples of the region must be strengthened. Regional cooperation will help to consolidate peace and thus reduce conflicts so that we have a second positive result: to limit the refugee flows that start from this region towards Europe. But this support must be free from liberal ideologies and not be aimed at profit because instead of addressing the causes of immigration, it will strengthen them.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, hundreds of thousands, millions of migrants waiting at the gates of Europe arriving today from the Middle East or Asian countries are more migrants whose arrival has been caused by crisis hot spots and wars. In the long run, however, there is no doubt that african citizens want to come to Europe to a great extent. That is why I strongly support this European Trust Fund for Africa because I believe that the very concept that Mr. Corrao has outlined in seven points, but I want to emphasize the point of long-termism of this project and the integrity of this Fund. Integrity in a way that really helps all key countries, but in the long term. This is a concept we have to go to and that is why I am one of those who really strongly want to express support for this Fund here.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are talking about the obvious: only the development of Africa, the development of the South, can socially stabilise these societies, it can stem this wave of immigration, which neither they nor we can cope with. We are in a situation of social instability. There have been a lot of voices about the fact that we cannot finance corrupt governments – that is also true.  However, what all these export recommendations for so-called sexual, reproductive, LGBTI, minority rights have in common with all of this, for example, in point 24. Many African leaders openly say that this is cultural imperialism. We impose our own problems on them instead of helping them. We really need to help them grow, not pass on our decadence to them.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, the migrants who try to set foot on European soil every day and those who die crossing the Mediterranean are like stones thrown in the face of the European Union – stones that remind them of the responsibilities it has had and has in underdevelopment, interference, destabilisation and war that are at the root of migration flows.  In view of this, the European Union, after the shameful agreement with Turkey, wants to extend to African countries the policy of outsourcing borders and managing migration flows, in the light of the interests and labour needs of the large European capital. A shame, even more so when we want to make development aid policy conditional on the acceptance of the European Union's migration policy and the submission to its principles.  An intolerable blackmail of neocolonial clipping on countries and peoples that find themselves in a position of enormous fragility. To the bottom of the causes of the migration flow implies a profound change in the policies and guidelines of the European Union and a genuine and enhanced development cooperation, respectful of the sovereignty and the right to development of African countries.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I completely agree with all of you who already focus on the root causes of this unprecedented crisis. I am sure that the EU Trust Fund for Africa definitely wants to focus on the root causes, and I am sure that this is our intention and our beliefs as Europeans. My experience on the ground has already convinced me that without dealing with the root causes there is no possibility to overcome and to see specific results on the ground. Please give me the chance before concluding to report on progress achieved so far by the EU Trust Fund. In approximately six months, 59 programmes have been approved across the three regions, for a total of EUR 927 million. We are now concluding a great number of contracts with implementers to start activities on the ground. Let me underline that funding in the countries of Sudan, South Sudan and Eritrea, is given only to partners, not to the governments. This is an important feature of our assistance. Migration issues are an integral part of our dialogue with African partners. In line with the new partnership framework endorsed by the European Council, the European Union is engaged in the process of developing comprehensive partnership ‘compacts’ with a limited number of initial countries of origin and transit. In addition to the nearly EUR two billion committed at Valletta, the Commission is ready to provide an additional EUR 500 million from the European Development Fund to finance actions in support of the new partnership approach, and calls upon EU Member States and other donors to match this additional contribution. So this is our initiative, and these are our activities making up the comprehensive approach in this very difficult area. I would like to reassure you that the Commission is fully committed to keeping the European Parliament and its relevant committees involved in the development of the EU Trust Fund for Africa, and we would like to continue via constant dialogue and regular sharing of the progress achieved.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank all my fellow Members who have spoken, I appreciate the constructive spirit that has been shown, I agree with many of the comments that have been made. Of course, I too am concerned that development money may end up with janjaweeds, horse devils who commit violence of all kinds in Sudan. I would like to thank the Commissioner for his comments.  I hope that this report will serve as a stimulus to fill some of the gaps in the Trust Fund and I hope that it will be a useful tool for effective action on the root causes of the migration crisis. The problem is a complex one and our aim must be to take a few steps, to move forward. Something has improved in the meantime: some NGOs, for example, have told us of an increase in transparency in the procedures that concern them, which were originally very confusing. We hope that this is the right way forward and we expect Parliament and the citizens to always be involved in the various processes concerning the Trust Fund.  The construction of this report has been marked by dialogue and the search for effective solutions. Tomorrow we will vote on both the text and the amendments which are mostly the result of this dialogue. I am sure that Parliament as a whole will be able to be united and decisive in voting on a text that deals with more sensitive and topical issues than ever before and also in sending a strong signal to the Commission and the Council.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. – The use of the EU Emergency Trust Fund to combat irregular migration to the EU is a disastrous and inhumane policy, which finances undemocratic and brutally repressive regimes such as those in Ethiopia and Sudan, and which are, in fact, the main drivers of migration flows to Europe.  Refugees and migrants flee wars, political persecution and tyranny, economic disgovernment and the lack of opportunities caused by oppressive kleptocracies. Financing corrupt and authoritarian regimes to create fences and barriers to control people and intensify the suffocation in which they live betrays our values and principles, is an ineffective and unsustainable policy, and a shameful waste of the resources of European taxpayers. The only way for the EU to have an effective migration management policy is to adopt a strategy to promote democracy, peace and conflict resolution and help create inclusive institutions that open up opportunities and genuine development and give people hope.  Europe that allows itself to be blackmailed and manipulated by oppressive governments loses credibility and destroys itself.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. – The EU Trust Fund for Africa is an important tool to strengthen stability in Africa and address the root causes of irregular and forced migration. The unclear migration flow clearly shows that the migration crisis cannot be contained without lasting stabilisation of the EU's neighbourhood.  Africa has the highest population growth in the world, with its relative share expected to reach 25% of the world's population in 2050. Member States need to do more to meet formal commitments, but it is also important to increase the flexibility of the EU budget in order to have more opportunities to respond to exceptional circumstances.  Despite its great capabilities, Europe cannot alone eliminate the root causes of migration problems. Therefore, more common approaches should be sought with international partners within the UN to address migration challenges and greater financial participation on their part. International law is applied equally worldwide and other high or middle-income countries could do more by increasing their financial support.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. – The creation of the European Union Emergency Trust Fund for Africa and the allocation of €1.8 billion in EU funding is an ad hoc response to the challenges we face, and it reminds us that we need a more flexible EU budget and greater budgetary reserves if we are to deal with unexpected crises more successfully in the future.  Despite the extraordinary circumstances that demand us to act quickly and effectively, we must not forget the legitimate, transparent and responsible use of the European Union budget. If we want to make full use of the potential of the Trust Fund, then we need a greater contribution from member states that have contributed less than 5% to the Fund. I would like the Member States to move from words to actions, to honour their commitments and contribute to the fund.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls the report by Tatjana 'adoka' and Vilija Blinkevi'i-tu, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on the establishment of working-life conditions in the labour market (2016/2017 (INI)) (A8-0253/2016).

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the report points to the need to makes changes to society. Having achieved the situation where women and men are equal earners and equal carers, there is a need for strong action at European, local and national levels for legislative measures, combined with non—legislative measures, in order to allow men and women to better reconcile work, caring for and spending time with family and friends and time for leisure and personal development. A labour market unable to provide flexible working arrangements and adequate-level schemes is a matter of everyday concern for a very high proportion of the population. The EU has to urgently adopt work-life balance policies – today’s reality – by taking into account the needs of an increasingly diverse society. In the report we call on the Commission to put forward a number of legislative proposals on family and care—related types of leave, namely a revised maternity leave directive, a paternity leave directive and a carers’ leave directive. Furthermore, Member States are in particular called upon to provide for accessible, available and affordable, high-quality care services for children, older relatives, family members with disabilities or those with illnesses. A specific part of the report is dedicated to the quality of employment. The crisis has also led to an increase in the numbers of the working poor throughout Europe, causing people to have to work more and longer hours, even combining several jobs, in order to earn a decent income. It is therefore important to ensure an inadequate wage for all workers and provide worker-oriented flexible working arrangements that do not cause an additional burden for the personal and family situation of both women and men.  Finally, labour market conditions favourable for work-life balance can only be created if quality of life is supported within and outside work. This means ensuring people have enough time outside work for personal development and leisure, and combating inequalities in society as a whole. We the co-rapporteurs are very satisfied with the outcome of the vote on the draft report by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. We regret, and are extremely anxious about, the large number of requests for split votes. We have all received the joint statement of 11 networks of NGOs – that is the text – who have been working together since 2012 in order to raise awareness about the daily challenges faced by women and men across the EU in reconciling their work, family and private life. These 11 networks of NGOs are calling on us to adopt this report in full to avoid undermining its comprehensive and coherent nature. I very much hope that colleagues will not ignore this request.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Rapporteur. – Thank you, Madam President. First of all, I thank the co-rapporteurs, Tatyana Ždanokai, and all the shadow rapporteurs for our joint work, because in fact this report is a contribution from the European Parliament, a reaction to the Commission's action plan on solutions to reconcile private life and work, especially for those families who raise children, and this is also a contribution to the public consultation and consultation with the social partners published by the Commission.  The issue is indeed very important, and we hope to receive legislative proposals from the Commission, because this is also a very topical topic in the Member States, because it affects every citizen of our country. In June this year, the Council adopted conclusions on gender equality, in which it stressed the need to adopt and strengthen legislative measures that would actually enable women and men to reconcile work, private and family life. I am pleased that we all want and pursue a common goal in this area. In the report, we therefore call on the Commission to present as soon as possible a new ambitious proposal for the Maternity Leave Directive, as well as the Carers' Leave Directive, which would allow family members to look after their dependent family members, people with disabilities or elderly family members and to ensure a certain level of social protection for them.  We also call on the Commission to come forward with a proposal for a Paternity Leave Directive providing for at least two weeks of fully paid parental leave, and finally we call for a revision of the Parental Leave Directive and for the minimum paid leave to be extended from four to six months, as women actually have to participate in the labour market, since the integration of women into the labour market is a key tool in the fight against poverty and social exclusion. However, if we encourage women to work and stay on the labour market for as long as possible, we must also provide all the conditions for equalising work and private life.  It is also important to stress that better coordination, co-ordination and access to different holidays in the Member States would certainly increase employment. We must also appreciate the rapid ageing of Europe, the facilitation of reconciling work and private life to enable parents to pay more attention to their families, while at the same time stimulating the birth rate. It is often the case that if families, especially women, fail to reconcile their professional activities with childcare, they are hesitant to have more children or decide not to have them at all. It is therefore not surprising that the European Union is facing the problem of a decline in birth rates.  It is therefore essential that a family-friendly environment is created in the workplace and that employers guarantee flexible working relationships for families with children and provide additional social guarantees. We need to ensure gender equality and a fair distribution of family responsibilities. Unfortunately, there is still a settled view that the problem of reconciliation between work and family is more often highlighted as a problem for women, as they bear the greatest burden of family care. We also really call on the Commission to introduce, during the semester, certain targeted monitoring indicators for the elderly and other dependants, similar to the Barcelona targets, and, in order for this process to take place, we call on Eurostat and Eurofound to collect relevant data and carry out studies in this area. Thus, there is no one-size-fits-all solution to reconcile work, personal and family life and we need to strike the right balance for every person to meet the professional, personal and family needs. Dear colleagues, I very much hope that tomorrow in the European Parliament there will be understanding and support for this report from all the political groups, and we must certainly send a message to the citizens of the European Union tomorrow that we are not blind to their problems. I very much ask for support in tomorrow's vote in favour of this report.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I thank my colleagues for submitting their report. I also consider it important for the European Parliament to talk about negative demographic developments in the EU and to look for measures to respond to the demographic decline. I also agree with the emphasis on family policy, with measures to strengthen job security and improve difficult working conditions. In view of the above reasons, I would expect the European Parliament to encourage member states to adopt a pro-family policy that values parental care, supports family members caring for both children and their needy members. And it will thus promote stable family relationships, because it is not only about material conditions, but also about the environment of security, security, trust and good relationships that the family provides and should provide. Instead, the EP calls on the Commission to recognise and also support all the diverse forms of relationships to replace the traditional family.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank my colleague Vilija Blinkevičiūtė for all her work on this report, which I know has taken some time. It is extremely important that the report takes a clear stand against austerity and widening social inequality. It highlights the sad reality that women are especially affected by precarious labour, zero-hour contracts and cuts in public services. The Commission and national governments must heed the call here and take action. It is an important example of how the EU promotes gender equality and social justice and why it is so important that we stand up for our core values. As Labour MEPs here in the European Parliament, we have a duty to draw attention to the important work done in this House. We must make sure that our constituents in the UK continue to benefit from the social protection enshrined in EU law, in any eventuality.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the initiatives taken so far, both at European and national level, to balance work and personal life have not brought the desired results. In fact, discrimination in the workplace between the sexes makes this harmonisation even more difficult for women. The types of leave linked to family reasons continue to be discriminatory despite existing legislation and, in countries such as Greece, the sharp wage differences and unemployment rates of 28.7% among women make them economically vulnerable. It is therefore necessary for the Union to take political action in order to address the socio-economic challenges created in the Member States of the European Union. However, as long as austerity policies continue to be imposed on the European countries of the South, harmonisation of personal and professional life and sustainable development will become even more difficult.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Madam President, I must say that I liked your reaction when you saw that I had picked up the paper and asked for catch the eye again. Not because I often apply for catch the eye and try to get catch the eye, but on this occasion I want to share my experience, 25 years in politics in a conservative country such as Croatia and an attempt to really create all possible conditions for gender equality and anti-discrimination access in the labour market, but also in politics itself.  When I created the lists of the party I ran for many years, I always tried to make at least one woman more than the men on the list. It's not simple. And it's good that men are talking about the subject. That's why I believe that great messages are what these reports from our colleagues say here and of course you will always have an ally in me for messages like this.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Madam President, decades of neoliberal policies, the imposition of austerity policies, impoverishment and exploitation by governments and the European Union mean serious social setbacks, resulting today with 125 million poor people, 30 million unemployed and an increasing inequality in the distribution of wealth. Policies that have crushed workers' rights and social achievements, which have attacked collective bargaining, which have imposed the devaluation of wages, the deregulation of working hours, the precariousness and the destruction and privatization of the public offering of family support services; class options, such as abandoning the maternity directive or leave that is not paid at 100 % where they exist; and policies, such as the European Semester, which some now try to wear with the cover of the social, concealing the practical consequences of its objectives, show that combating inequalities and raising the living conditions of workers will only be possible with the necessary rupture with right-wing policies.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Madam President, little needs to be said. I think things are pretty clear. Of course, for the compatibility of working life and family life, what needs to be taken is, as the colleague has said, clear and decisive measures, and the European Commission's policy so far what it is doing is to hide and set aside what had already been agreed here, such as the call for European legislation for parental and maternal leave. We therefore consider that, if this development is not changed, if that direction is not changed in the work of the European Commission, of course we will never have real conciliation and a real possibility of reconciling that working life and family life, something which, we remember, is fundamental to equality strategies and which is contained in all the Treaties of this European Union. It will not be possible if that political direction is not changed.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I, of course, also see a positive moment in this report, such as the right-to-rest thing, with the alignment of the issues of truly family life with the conditions of the labour market. There are a number of positive moments, but I would also like to stress some negative ones. In my opinion, labour law is already bound by a number of regulations. I think that the European Parliament should not become a paternalist, it is precisely from this point of view that we enter into labour relations, it is a matter of collective bargaining. I would very much hate for the EP to become, to some extent, a trade union for all workers in the labour market. I think that this is also the case with the principle of subsidiarity protection, that the Member States themselves should be able to do their own work on this matter. I have serious reservations about this report.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, when we talk about the European Parliament, which should not be a trade union, I would like to say that, despite the constant demands of the national trade unions, but also of the European union, the Commission, in 2015, decided to abandon the revision of the maternity leave directive on the grounds that this directive was not modern and did not fulfil the requirements of a new world in terms of work-life balance. Today, this report, and I would particularly like to thank the two co-reports, seems to me to be complete, balanced and modern. It does propose a legislative approach to parental leave - maternity, paternity and parental leave. If it is not modern on the new distribution of roles, what is more modern?  It offers a "children' guarantee" for children who do not have a childcare facility, for the most disadvantaged children. Here, too, it is a question of breaking the vicious cycle of poverty. Finally, this report also proposes to enshrine this as a fundamental right in the pillar of social rights.  I think it is really an extremely modern report and I thank the co-reports.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Madam President, Europe faces a great challenge, namely demographic change. Life expectancy has increased, birth rates remain low, children appear at more advanced ages of the mother, family structures change and new forms of relationship building are emerging, plus the phenomenon of migration.  In addition, the economic and financial crisis has led to budget cuts in public funds for work-life balance policies. As such, better cooperation between the Commission and the Member States is needed to implement positive policies and support demographic renewal, encourage greater participation of grandparents, and maintain social security systems.  Finally, I would like to congratulate the two rapporteurs on their approach in this report, which has reached all the key points relating to balancing family and professional life.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, today, the balance between private and professional life is increasingly difficult to find. Young people are forced to have more jobs to ensure a decent living for their families. The risk of unemployment pushes employees to work overtime, and competition generates high-risk health stressors. I worked in the field of human resources and often met people who regretted not having time for their private life. But to protect today's employees, not just the work schedule, but a number of factors, sometimes used by employers, that put pressure on employees and privacy. We need European legislation that introduces greater flexibility to ensure a balanced family life. We need mechanisms that actively combat the means used to push employees to devote themselves especially to working life. The European Commission to come up with an ambitious proposal and, above all, the family must become a factor of stability again because a balanced private life leads to a successful working life.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, firstly I would like to thank, on behalf of my dear colleagues Commissioners Marianne Thyssen and Věra Jourová, the two rapporteurs, Ms Ždanoka and Ms Blinkevičiūtė. The Commission shares many of your analyses and conclusions.  Parenting – and caring more generally – is no longer only the role of women. To care is to be human, and anyone can become a carer. In fact, many men would like to spend more time with their families, but do not have the possibility or are somehow discouraged from doing so. But the Commission believes that, if a woman wants to be more active on the labour market, making the most of her high level of educational attainment, she should have the possibility to do so, even when she has children or when relatives get older or ill. And the same is valid for a working man who wants to be more present at home to be with his young children or care for his relatives. This report comes at the right moment: it supports our ongoing initiative to improve work-life balance for working parents and caregivers. We welcome very much the work and effort of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs to draw attention to these important challenges and to suggest interesting options.  The Commission’s aim now is to present a more holistic approach to addressing the challenges of work-life balance. We have an existing EU legal framework in this field and policy instruments such as policy guidance, benchmarks and monitoring. But these are not enough. Both the legal instruments and the policy measures need to be modernised and updated. First, to enable both women and men to realise their potential in the labour market. Second, to support employers to have the skills they need. Third, to combat discrimination, and fourth, to reduce the gender-based exposure to poverty and achieve gender equality.  We are envisaging a comprehensive package with both legislative and non-legislative elements to support working families and businesses. The challenges for working parents start with the arrival of a new baby and continue into childhood and the teenage years. There needs to be a decent level of childcare and care services infrastructure in place to give people a meaningful choice. And we must not forget the challenges of caring for elderly or infirm dependants faced by today’s ‘sandwich generation’.   We want to propose up-to-date solutions to meet real needs. We are now running the second consultation with social partners, seeking their views on possible avenues for EU legislative action. We also held a broad public consultation which ended in February this year.  The views expressed by experts and key stakeholders point to the need for developing and implementing a range of non-legislative EU measures such as policy guidance, improved monitoring, better utilisation of EU funds and knowledge-sharing activities. Subject to the social partners’ prerogative to negotiate, it is the Commission’s intention to accompany this process. If the social partners decide not to enter into negotiation, the Commission intends to explore all avenues leading to the establishment of an effective legislative and policy framework. You have seen this commitment in our work programme, and we are pleased to have your support in this endeavour. We will tackle these challenges together, for working men and women across Europe.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – The reconciliation between working and family life remains an outstanding subject in Europe and represents an obstacle to achieving real equality between men and women. We want to send a clear message to the Commission to update and complete European legislation. It must submit as soon as possible a revision of the maternity directive, an improvement in the parental leave directive and two new directives, one on paternity leave and one on the leave of carers. It is also important to improve the provision of quality services at affordable prices for childcare and other dependents, so that women, who are the majority among caregivers, can participate in the labour market and qualify for full-time jobs, which allow them to generate a decent pension for the future. It is also necessary to rationalize working hours and introduce greater flexibility so that all workers can enjoy their private life, because this not only improves the well-being of people, but also benefits companies since people with a satisfactory work-private balance are more productive at work.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The report adopted is very complex and takes up many strands, but this shows well that we should have a holistic approach to work-life balance. That is why I voted in favour of this report. The report pays a lot of attention to parental leave and equal sharing of care by both parents. I believe that this is extremely important and solutions should be promoted that will allow mothers and dads to exercise their right to care freely in a way that is optimal not only for their careers and private lives, but above all for the best interests of the child.  I am pleased that the report also includes provisions on innovative solutions that can be introduced in the workplace. I believe that opportunities such as teleworking and part-time work should be used and, where possible, working time should be made more flexible. Of course, this should be done on the basis of bilateral arrangements between the employer and the employee and in no case should it be compulsory.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The subject raised in this report is very important both for the societies of the Member States and for the EU economy. However, it is very complex and touches on cultural issues, which requires the European Union to be extremely careful in the selection of instruments and in shaping legislation. Nevertheless, we must bear in mind that there are now some objective processes, which some experts call the second demographic transition. We are dealing with a redefinition of the family model and a radical decline in fertility. The so-called nuclear family goes down in history. In order to continue to grow economically, the Union needs to adapt to the new times and, above all, to stem the negative demographic trend. However, as the rapporteurs rightly points out, there are no one-size-fits-all solutions in all Member States.  Nevertheless, decisive action is needed, including, above all, family-friendly policies. Therefore, while I agree that a review of the Maternity Directive is needed, I believe that a certain sensitivity is needed in the preparation of legislative proposals, given the cultural differences in paternity and carers' leave. Certainly, the Commission must strictly respect the principle of subsidiarity, otherwise it may be that these legislative acts will be blocked, whether by governments in the Council or by national parliaments.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " The reconciliation of work and private life is an increasing challenge of the present day. The rising cost of living means that few families can afford to have one parent stay at home with their children. As a rule, both are forced to work or look for work. This has a negative impact on the quality of life of families, but also often on fertility, as families struggle to decide on offspring, which threatens demographic collapse. That is why employee guarantees are so important, especially for mothers who want to return to work after having a child. It is therefore pleased that the report adopted by the Committee on Employment and the Committee on Women's Rights draws attention in several places to the need to preserve the right of return to work, as well as other facilities particularly important for young mothers, i.e. flexible working hours, provided that they arise from the needs of the worker and are adapted to his or her abilities.  Another important element of the report, with which I agree, is the need to ensure that families with children are not condemned to deterioration in their financial situation. That is why support programmes are so important, such as Polish 500+ programme supporting parenthood, which is clearly welcomed by families.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - The birth rate in the European Union has decreased in recent decades and the Union faces worrying demographic challenges. Work insecurity and difficult working conditions are reflected negatively on family planning. To this end, the European Union needs targeted and proactive policies to support family life. The plan presented by the Commission is not a final solution, but it is certainly a good starting point for fostering positive demographic trends.  Work-life balance policies must be well designed, as they are essential to improve the working environment that consequently generates good working conditions and social and business well-being. This applies, inter alia, to gender inequalities in paid and unpaid work and to promoting equal sharing of responsibilities, costs and childcare.  Particularly concerned is the fact that there is still a significant gender pay gap, which is not beable for the values we espouse in the European Union. In my view, the guidance set out in the report on creating favourable labour market conditions for achieving a work-life balance is a good starting point for work-family life balance that should be guaranteed as a fundamental right for all people, without gender discrimination.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – I am saddened by the fact that women still too often face discrimination on the labour market, which is unacceptable in the 21st century.  In concrete terms, we can see that the conditions for the reconciliation of private and professional life are particularly visible in larger cities, where the lack of space in kindergartens makes it difficult for women to reconcile their careers with their private lives due to a lack of space in kindergartens.  In most European countries, men and women are still not equal carers. A good example and an example can be my country, Slovenia. In addition to maternity and maternity benefits and parental leave, our citizens are also entitled to paternity leave, which allows men to participate on an equal and assistance to women in caring for a child.  The Commission and the Member States must develop policies and measures that will facilitate work-life balance. Investment in infrastructure and the construction of new kindergartens and nursing homes is also essential.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the Regulation).

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Madam President, in deciding to close its headquarters in Gosselies, Belgium, Caterpillar is causing a social earthquake: more than 2,000 direct jobs, more than 6,000 if we count the subcontractors who depend directly on it. This decision is all the more unacceptable because it is taken in complete disregard of local, regional and national employees and political authorities. By 2013, Caterpillar had already cut 1,200 jobs. The employees and their trade union organization have shown great responsibility to save the activity of the site by making numerous concessions. For all thanks, they find themselves outside, while the American leadership does not even have the courage to explain itself and flouts the basic rules of social dialogue. This disaster imposes a rapid response in terms of supporting employees, but not only. There is an urgent need for an ambitious industrial policy and to boost investment.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Madam President, women in Europe, especially those in rural and small urban areas, continue to face serious difficulties in finding work and maintaining financial stability, preventing and identifying health problems for pregnant women, support for combating discrimination and acts of physical and verbal violence. These problems have a direct negative impact on the well-being of families in the Member States of the European Union. In Romania we have made some public policy proposals that I believe the European institutions could take over and finance throughout the Union. These cover facilities for rural women to find stable jobs, support for rural children with mothers who have gone to work in the community, campaigns to prevent the risk of breast cancer, free analysis for pregnant women. Through close collaboration between institutions, civil society and governments we can find solutions point-by-point to these problems.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the recent negative decision of the Committee on Petitions on Germany's debts to Greece is morally unacceptable and politically completely biased. It is a disgrace to the European Union itself, which is washing its hands like a young Pontius Pilate on the issue of German war reparations. It is a historic challenge to the Greek fighters of the National Resistance but also to the peoples of Europe who did not bow their heads to the Nazi beast. It is a great demonstration that the European Union has now turned into a German Europe that is trying to change even history itself. It is a decision that further crushes Berlin, as shown by today's provocative statements by the representative of the German Chancellor, Stephen Zybert, stating that the issue of German reparations has supposedly been settled. Of course, the Commission and the various memorial powers in the European Parliament were encouraged by the provocative indifference shown by the Tsipras government for not supporting the reporting of the National Resistance fighters (PEAE/DSE). But we are not going to give up: the fight for German reparations continues.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The forthcoming elections in Bosnia and Herzegovina have prompted some politicians to call for one of the country's two entities, republika srpska, to hold a referendum on their unity day. This is despite the fact that the Supreme Court of Bosnia has declared that it is contrary to its secular form of government. I have some, limited understanding of political election campaigns in the chasing of voters, but playing with such things in Bosnia can end very badly. This referendum not only challenges the country's sovereignty, security and constitution, but it spreads fear of armed conflict. We must not let this flame light up again and back the country back to the 90s. No elections and no voters are worth jeopardising the difficult peace in the Balkans.  That is why the Commission must act. If we do not show now that peace and stability are not negotiable, we can never ask others to do so again. The Commission must urgently demand that this illegal vote be put to an end.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, in Portugal, the path of devolution of rights and income to workers and pensioners and the reversal of some of the more negative aspects of the previous Government's policy, although far below what is necessary, this path, although modest and limited, unadidly clashes with the european union's impositions. It is clear that any political solution that challenges the dominant political orientation, which has brought Europe, and in particular the Eurozone, to an unprecedented crisis is to implode. This is the meaning of the intolerable process of open sanctions against Portugal and the blackmail associated with it in relation to the suspension of funds, aiming to condition the discussion and preparation of the State Budget for 2017.  It is no surprise, it just makes clearer the need for a break with impositions and blackmail, the need to regain monetary sovereignty, a currency of its own, a central bank unbound from the ECB, financial, exchange and budgetary management adjusted to the needs of the country, along with a renegotiation of debt, terms, interest and amounts and the recovery of public control over the banking sector.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Madam President, the Spanish Ministry of The Environment says that it has begun the process of declaring as a specially protected area of importance for the Mediterranean the cetacean corridor that runs between the coasts of the Balearic Islands and those of the Valencian Country and Catalonia. The European Commission supports the project and yet at the same time the Spanish Government maintains and extends permits to carry out prospects in that area. While the Spanish Government wants to give the image of an environmental defender, it authorizes activities that threaten biodiversity and also the economic future of areas, especially the Balearic Islands, which have tourism as the basis of their economy. The European Commission has in its hands the complaint of the citizen platform Alianza Mar Blava, which describes the irregularities that the Spanish Government committed in granting those permits, including non-compliance with European rules. But keep quiet. I call on the European Commission from here to react, to listen to the citizens and scientists who have alerted them to the danger posed by these prospects and to be involved in stopping these aberrant projects.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in my region, Sicily, there are still some 5 000 hectares of oxygen-producing, income-producing, wealth-producing and job-producing plants. I'm talking about plants that produced this fruit here: lemon, this citrus.  In this House, which voted for free trade agreements, such as the EU-Morocco Treaty, which did so without ensuring traceability requirements, product labelling requirements, there are colleagues who have most likely never known the taste of a real lemon, a real Sicilian lemon, yet they have acted, affecting an entire production sector.  I say that solutions exist, and they have existed for decades: we are talking about amending the traceability directive, we are talking about activating safeguard clauses, and these are things that we can do and that we should really think about doing as soon as possible.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a few weeks ago, as we all know, a terrible earthquake devastated three regions of my country. A few minutes ago I heard the very combative mayor of one of the most heavily affected municipalities, Mayor Pirozzi of Amatrice, who said to me: if you have the chance, speak in the Chamber in Strasbourg, with a view to the arrival in the earthquake areas of a delegation from the European Commission, ensure that these Commissioners speak directly with us mayors, who represent the people, so that aid is monitored. , arrive early, because these people do not want to leave their territory, they are about to face a certainly fearsome winter, they want help so that they can start working and producing again, because they are populations attached to their territory, but also to their work, tenaciously and constantly, in their demand to be able to save their country, their identity, their work. Europe must do what is necessary now.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Madam President, recently the Committee on Petitions of the European Parliament, insulting the thousands of victims of Nazi atrocities in Greece, he rejected a report by the Panhellenic Association of National Resistance Fighters/Democratic Army of Greece, whose representatives are here in Strasbourg tomorrow to give a press conference on the continued for decades provocative refusal of the German governments to pay war reparations for Nazi crimes, in violation of the international agreement of Paris on war reparations, which only Greece received despite having, proportionally, had the most victims. 71 years after the anti-fascist victory of the peoples, the victims are objectively condemned again, the slaughterers are acquitted. Only Happy Golden Dawn and Hitler's other nostalgics. Despite the big mouth, the unacceptable provocative refusal of the Greek governments and the current SYRIZA-ANEL to claim reparations by serving the international alliances of the Greek bourgeoisie reinforces German intransigence. The Communist Party will escalate its fight for this just popular demand as a blood donor and leader of the National Resistance.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: – Madam President, I would like to express my deep indignation at the fact that, although the Commission acknowledged in December that Ukraine had already complied with the visa liberalisation plan, bureaucratic procedures are still hindering the visa-free entry of citizens. While Europe is overstrested by hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants without any id documents, Ukrainian citizens belonging to the European community, including Hungarians from Transcarpathia, even with visas, have to wait for hours at the few available border crossing points. The citizens of Ukraine have made many sacrifices for European orientation, in return for which the EU has not made this symbolic gesture without delay. I therefore call for the Ukrainian dossier to be treated in accordance with its importance and to take the necessary steps to grant visa waivers as soon as possible and to draw up a development and budget plan for the extension of border infrastructure in order to improve international routes and border crossings, because this would finally be a tangible help for citizens.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the crisis on trust in the European Union is seriously affecting the future of Europe. After poor management of the refugee crisis, repeated terrorist attacks and Brexit, European citizens need clear communication from the Commission, but also measures on their safety, improving the quality of life, respect for human rights, no matter what European country they live in.  Unfortunately, the Commission, almost half a mandate away, does not have a clear and well-communicated and explained crisis strategy for European citizens. How could citizens' confidence in the European Union, in the Commission, increase if citizens do not see positive changes in their lives.  One example is the Strategic Investment Fund: it has not had any positive effects in the eastern countries and this is leading to increased regional disparities. I call on the Commission, on behalf of the citizens I represent, to take into account the provisions of the Treaty and with regard to safety, but also with regard to social cohesion. We cannot continue with two Europes, Schengen and non-Schengen. The citizens of my country feel rightly discriminated against.  I believe that the European Union is at a crossroads and there is a need for a review of the strategy, but also of the way of communication, if we want a united Europe.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, what is the future of the European Union after Brexit? When I listen to some speeches here and I watch some colleagues and colleagues, I feel like I saw it all together 25 years ago. Namely, I mean what we watched when Yugoslavia was falling apart.  Could Brexit really be a prelude to the break-up of the European Union? Personally, I don't want that. In fact, I want the exact opposite. I want the talks that were the other day about strengthening the defence systems of the European Union, about the greater connection that the members of the Visegrad Group discussed, about some Confederate or federal model. I see this as the future of the European Union.  But on the other hand, if we don't change policy objectively and quickly in this Parliament as well, we risk disintegration more than success.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Madam President, I have just come from the Calais camp and the situation there is sincerely disgraceful. Six months after the last of forced evictions began, the camp's population has increased by 3,000 people, while the area left to occupy has been significantly reduced, worsening overcrowded conditions. Opposite, on the sides of the road leading to the UK, a concertina wall is increased in height and surveillance with a budget of 17 million euros. It is the vivid image of the 'Fortress Europe': on the one hand, the misery in which refugees fleeing war live and, head-on, the violent response of security forces and exorbitant budgets of walls as high as useless; all to create a feeling of totally false inability to manage, that sense of invasion that so much likes the right, whether extreme or popular. With real political commitment, we must give rights to anyone who needs it. No one takes their share of this, but we already know who pays for the duck: thousands and thousands of refugees inside and outside the Union.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Madam President, yesterday, 11 September 2016, almost one million people took to the streets and squares of Catalonia again to celebrate their national holiday and to cry out for the independence of Catalonia. That happened yesterday for the fifth year in a row. There has not been such a huge and sustained cry in Europe as it is in my country. But the Spanish Government, contrary to all democratic logic, repeatedly refuses to call a referendum, such as the one that took place in Scotland, so that everyone can know whether or not the will for independence is majority in Catalonia. Today, in celebrating yesterday's success, I would also like to denounce again in this House the undemocratic refusal of the Spanish authorities, because, in a democracy, the law is not used to gag freedom; in a democracy what is really law is the will of the people. In Spain he has forgotten. In Catalonia we remember and demand.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Apparently no one here has learned anything from Brexit. This week, the German government and France come up with the great new idea of an EU-army with EU-military research and EU budget. The Commission is planning EU unemployment insurance and a euro-zone budget, as well as minimum tax rates for certain revenues. And as if all this were not enough, we are now working diligently to provide the EU with its own tax collection rights, to provide it with other own resources and, for example, to grant it the CO2 tax or the EU motorway vignette.  The British have not even set foot out of the EU, and many here are already thinking of enforcing the EU superstate with particular intensity. I have the impression that you have not learned anything, that you do not want to learn anything, that you have not learned anything and that you will probably not learn anything: people do not want that; the next referendums will, fortunately, show this.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to comment today in my one minute on a subject that to some extent breaks down the boundaries of expression in France, for example, and that is the issue of covering women with burkinas. I do not want to comment on this subject as a member of the EP, but as one who wants the principle of subsidiarity to be respected in the EU institutions. I want to speak out against such topics being brought into the debate just before the EP in order to address national policy. I think that our decision-making and our actions should be focused on what is really the content of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU and on the functioning of their institutions. I am absolutely certain that we should not violate the principle of subsidiarity on a number of other issues, for the reason that the EU should, above all, be a body that operates in accordance with the member states, the governments of those Member States, and that it provides a good service to citizens in defined policies.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, for decades the EU has channelled vital funding to the northeast of England, my home region. Between 2014 and 2020 we were set to receive over half a billion pounds sterling in regional and social funding. This money underpins our local economy, securing thousands of jobs, developing key infrastructure and driving real innovation and excellence in our region. Following the Brexit vote, there is a real danger that one of the poorest English regions could be heavily out of pocket. We were promised by the Leave campaigners that Brexit would make us richer and that these funds would be protected, but ministers have only committed to underwriting contracts concluded by the autumn statement. That is just not good enough. Tonight I call on the British Government to guarantee that all EU funds promised are delivered and that long-term investment in regions like mine is guaranteed.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, is the Commission apolitical? Well, recent statements by Moscovici and Vestager about the EUR 13 billion simply waiting for Ireland to collect have convinced me that it is not. They have said Ireland can spend all of this money on hospitals and schools, yet they know that many other countries, including the US are already lining up to get their fair share of the cake, and that whatever share is left for Ireland will be a fraction. Yet they have dangled what I now call the ‘Brussels bribe’ in front of our noses. Our French Commissioner rubbed our noses in it by expressing his surprise: the Irish did not want this money in light of the crisis. This is the self-same Commission that, as part of the Troika, forced us to shoulder over 60% of the cost of the crisis and to pay unsecured bondholders, some of whom, I have no doubt, were in French banks. It reminds me of the Brexiteers who promised EUR 350 million per week to the UK National Health Service if people voted to leave. It is the worst kind of politics from the Commission: promising what you cannot deliver.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, the then Fianna Fáil Government’s response to the financial and banking crisis in Ireland included well-known pillars such as the burdening of private debt on ordinary families and the imposition of a savage austerity agenda, but it also included another pillar, the establishment of NAMA (the National Asset Management Agency), set up as a ‘bad bank’ – although even those of us who opposed its creation failed to imagine just how bad it would become. It is now clear that NAMA’s sale in 2014 of its Project Eagle property portfolio in the North of Ireland was based on bribery and insider trading. Assets were sold to a US vulture fund at a shocking discount of 72% – billions below their value. All NAMA transactions must be suspended immediately. It is clear that the Irish Government cannot delay a commission of investigation much longer. Irish taxpayers should not have to wait for another state aid investigation to get to the truth about how they have been fleeced.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, the many threats facing Europe’s bee population, including those of environmental changes and the Varroa parasite, are well known, but it is my duty to address the appalling lack of focus and public attention being given to the spread of the small hive beetle in southern Italy. This parasite has been wreaking havoc on Italian beekeepers for over two years and despite serious eradication efforts similar to the failed attempts in the United States, Canada and Australia, the small hive beetle has now established itself in Italy, and what is more, it is there to stay.  Tonight I call for the immediate ban on the export of all Italian queen bees and the placing of a movement ban on Italian hives. Unless such drastic steps are taken, our honeybees face extinction. British and European beekeepers are calling for this, but, to their despair, no one listens. Action must now be taken or it will be too late.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Madam President, elections to the Russian Duma, the lower house of the Parliament of the Russian Federation, are due to take place on 18 September 2016. It will take place not only on the territory of the Russian Federation, but also take place in the occupied Crimea. With these elections, the Kremlin is trying to legitimize the results of the so-called March 16, 2014 referendum in the eyes of the international community.  I would like to stress that, despite all the efforts of Russian diplomacy and the costly kremlin-led media disinformation campaign under current international law (e.g. UN General Assembly Resolution 68/262), the status of this peninsula is unequivocal. It is an integral part of Ukraine. Any questioning of this is an attempt to destabilise respect for international obligations and territorial sovereignty.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, even unfinished, the action for The UK's exit from the European Union has brought with it uncertainty and warnings from the external partners of the European Union, as well as of the large companies whose operations targeting the European market are headquartered in the United Kingdom. Following a study, Japan's government recently expressed concerns about the future of investments in Europe by big Japanese companies. In this context, Japanese officials clearly mention the European Medicines Agency and have reservations about the continuation of the work of Japanese citizens in this institution. That is why the proposal That I made before you at the last session, to move the headquarters of the European Medicines Agency from the United Kingdom to Romania, becomes of the utmost importance, and speed is essential so that the effective exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union does not bring with it syncope and an insurmountable disorder of the institution's activity. Romania is one of the countries of the European Union with a long tradition in pharmaceutical research, but also in the production and study of medicines. I take this opportunity and invite you to join the release of a written statement on the subject. The time has come for us Members of the European Parliament to demonstrate that we are campaigning and acting for a European Union of solidarity, where Member Nations enjoy the same trust.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, the British Government, not content with dragging the people of the North of Ireland out of the EU, are now keeping us in the dark about their intentions for our future. Theresa May’s Government is divided and confused. Brexit means Brexit, but what does it mean for the people of England, Scotland or Wales and for the people in the North of Ireland? They do not know, and that is hurting communities and businesses. Both the British and Irish Governments must immediately explore ways by which the democratic wishes of the people of the North of Ireland can be respected. Fifty-six per cent of the people voted to remain – so they need to listen to the people, including human rights groups, language activists, children’s campaigners, businesses, the voluntary and community sector, students, farmers and political parties, who all said loud and clear: ‘remain means remain’. Hundreds and thousands of us in the North of Ireland have Irish passports and that means we are EU citizens, therefore remain must mean remain.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: – Madam President, one of the problems of the European Union is the question of credibility. Last year, I had a debate with Vice-President Timmermans in the Committee on Petitions on indigenous european national minorities. At the time, he suggested I write a project to address the problems I had outlined. I did, and the project received the highest professional rating from the European Commission, and the LIBE Committee assessed it in the same way. Following a decision by the European Parliament last December, the project has become part of this year's Budget of the European Union with a grant of EUR 1 million. The project is called "Diverse Europe". The Commission promised to launch the programme in January, but this did not happen. Then february, April, then June, and later the beginning of September became the date of publication – but nothing has happened to date. I find the Commission's procedure unacceptable, which I will also say here, by letter to Mr Juncker, and if nothing happens by October, so will the press.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, today, more than three million pupils and preschoolers have started a new school year in Romania. As every year, we think about the extent to which the education system offers a better future for our children. Too often, education is seen as a cost, when in fact it is an investment in how the world will look and how our children can achieve their dreams. This approach makes it possible, beyond the purpose of education, to finance figures, instead of worrying about students, to mathematically account for destinies, instead of guiding our young people and getting stuck in bureaucratic mechanisms, instead of adapting the system to today's needs. The European left, through the voice of the Party of European Socialists, has proposed a series of measures through the Youth Pact, in which it seeks to convince European decision-makers that strong, coherent, consistent action is needed to support the next generation. As a young Member of the European Parliament, I think it is my duty to tell you that today young people in Romania want education to become a competence of the European Union and thus become, as I said earlier, a priority on the European agenda.

name: Andor DELI
text: – Madam President, the goal of each western Balkan state is to join the European Union. This political ambition cannot be overlooked or neglected because it could easily cause accession fatigue. I am glad to see that the European People’s Party is working very intensively with the western Balkan countries. The presence of the EPP and, through that, the presence of Christian democratic values in the region is of great importance. This was underpinned by yesterday’s election victory of the HDZ in Croatia but the EPP was also very active in the resolution of political stalemates in Macedonia and Bosnia-Herzegovina. I would like especially to emphasise the ambition of the governing Serbian Progressive Party (SNS) to become an associate member of the EPP. We will see the final decision on this request in November. Through that the EPP will gain a strong member party which would greatly help in terms of its ambition to fortify stability in the region.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am ed to draw attention to the very tense situation that we are facing in relation to Turkey. As a member of the EMPL Committee, I was due to visit Turkey next week, but unfortunately this trip is cancelled in view of the current situation, which does not ensure either security or that we will visit the institutions we were supposed to be talking to. Similarly, the trips of other committees have been postponed. I am very concerned about this situation in view of Turkey's pressure to speed up the introduction of visa-free travel and also in view of the overall developments in Turkey. I personally consider it very important that the EU-Turkey agreement be implemented and that we also have the opportunity to personally see turkey's compliance with the terms of this agreement. However, if we have to go to Turkey and we are not provided with information and information is not provided to the security services, then we will not be able to agree to the introduction of visa-free travel.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: This item on the agenda is closed.
